{"id": "6062", "title": "Herald.ie", "uri": "herald.ie"}, "url": "http://www.herald.ie/sport/soccer/barca-close-to-a-deal-for-coutinho-36043417.html", "body": "Barcelona general manager Pep Segura has said the signings of Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele are \"close\" after watching his side lose to arch-rivals Real Madrid in the Supercopa de Espana final.\n\nLiverpool have remained adamant that Brazilian playmaker Coutinho - who has submitted a transfer request - will not be sold in this transfer window while Borussia Dortmund suspended Dembele after the forward failed to show for training amid links with Barcelona.\n\nHowever, Segura expressed confidence deals for both players could be done before the transfer window closes.\n\n\"We are close to Coutinho and Dembele,\" he said on Catalan television. \"We are discussing their deals but do not know when it will be done.\"\n\nAsked if he expected them to sign, he added: \"Yes, we expect it.\"\n\nReports in Spain on Wednesday suggested Barca had agreed a fee with Dortmund for French winger Dembele.\n\nBarca are looking to replace Neymar following his shock world record transfer to Paris St Germain, and their need for reinforcements was apparent as they lost 2-0 to Madrid on Wednesday night, completing a 5-1 aggregate loss to the Spanish and European champions.\n\nStrengthen\n\n\"We know we have to strengthen this team and that is what we are doing,\" Segura added. \"We have to help the team.\" Liverpool manager Jurgen Klopp has dismissed Barcelona claims that a deal for wantaway playmaker Philippe Coutinho is close to completion.\n\nThe club have rejected two bids from Barcelona, the last 100million euros (\u00a390.9m), and a week ago issued a defiant statement insisting no offers would be considered and the player would remain at the club beyond the summer window.\n\nCoutinho, who is currently sidelined with a back injury, immediately handed in a transfer request and after Wednesday night's Spanish Super Cup defeat to Real Madrid Pep Segura, Liverpool's former academy technical manager and now Barcelona's general manager, told Catalan television: \"We are close to Coutinho and (Ousmane) Dembele.\n\n\"We are discussing their deals but do not know when it will be done.\" Asked if he expected them to sign, he added: \"Yes, we expect it.\"\n\nHowever, Klopp is adamant there have been no more developments and the two clubs are not even in discussions.\n\n\"I saw the game (Real-Barcelona) but I forgot to watch the interviews afterwards. Nothing to say from our side,\" said the Reds boss.\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they are saying; I don't even know them - especially this guy, I've never even met him.\"\n\nAsked whether there had been any subsequent talks Klopp added: \"I am not sure I have to answer this only because we have said what we have to say, or the club said what we have to say.\n\n\"No news from me because no-one told me anything different since we spoke last time about this.\"\n\nImpossible\n\nThere have been suggestions Coutinho could agitate for a move by effectively going on strike but while he is still injured that is impossible.\n\nKlopp was asked about the prospect of this and the Brazil international's general attitude.\n\n\"To be honest I have nothing to say about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he has obviously not been in training,\" he said.\n\n\"I asked the medical department how he is doing and there are no complaints so that is how it is. There is nothing bad to say about this. We are all not silly. We know it is a very difficult situation but there is nothing new to say. It is not always easy for me to say the 100 per cent truth - even though I don't like to like - but it is exactly how I say it because that is how it is in the moment, nothing else.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Paulinho is ready to meet the challenges facing Barcelona this season \"with courage\" after moving to the Nou Camp for \u20ac40million.\n\nSpeaking at his Nou Camp unveiling yesterday, he said: \"You have to face challenges with courage. I will try to do my job and I am prepared.\n\n\"Coming here is a dream. It's a very satisfying moment. I will give everything.\"\n\nOn social media a number of Barca fans have begun to call for the resignation of club president Josep Maria Bartomeu, who has overseen the modest recruitment drive that {"id": "9649084", "categories": [{"id": 256, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Competitions", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/Competitions", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 284, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Literature/Drama", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Literature/Drama", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710784890", "source": {"id": "205", "title": "Mirror", "uri": "mirror.co.uk"}, "url": "http://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/philippe-coutinho-transfer-liverpool-barcelona-10997866", "body": "The Reds are doing all they can to keep hold of their prized asset but their heads could be turned before the window closes\n\nGet football updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nIt's the transfer saga that has dragged all summer.\n\nWill he? Won't he? Who knows!\n\nPhilippe Coutinho's future at Liverpool remains up in the air with just two weeks of the transfer window reamining.\n\nBarcelona are determined to spend their Neymar cash on new additions and will keep working until the end of the window to try and get the deal over the line.\n\nBut where is the deal up to now? With so many new lines emerging every day, Mirror Football has rounded up the latest situation.\n\nSo, without further ado, here's what we know...\n\nTHE FACTS... Coutinho wants to leave\n\nSorry, Liverpool fans. There's no getting away from the fact of the matter.\n\nBy handing in a transfer request earlier this month, Coutinho confirmed that he did indeed want to leave for Barcelona.\n\nThere is a perception that Coutinho believes that if he cannot secure the move away this summer, he might never get to go - and that is why he is actively trying to secure the move this summer.\n\nLiverpool emphatic that they don't want to sell\n\nThe said transfer request was firmly rejected by Liverpool.\n\nAt the same time, Liverpool turned down two separate offers for his services - one being as large as \u00a390million.\n\n\"It's not that I don't want to talk about it, it's that I can't change my answers - because there is nothing else to say,\" Jurgen Klopp said with almost a grimace in his most recent press conference.\n\n\"If they [Barcelona] say they will bid whatever money, we don't want it. It is a clear message. The owners are 100 per cent clear on it.\n\n\"We don't want money, we want to invest in the team and have the best team because we have our aims and dreams. That is the message.\"\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now Barcelona remain keen to do the deal\n\nBarcelona want to reinvest the cash from the deal to sell Neymar back into their squad.\n\nWhile they are closing in on a deal for Borussia Dortmund forward Ousmane Dembele, Barca are also hopeful of landing Coutinho as they bid to make up for the loss of one of their star players.\n\nThey have seen two approaches turned down by Liverpool, but don't appear set to give up on the fight.\n\nCoutinho is injured - but remains in training\n\nCoutinho cut a glum figure when he arrived for training at Melwood earlier this week.\n\nHe remains based at Liverpool's training ground as he recovers from a back problem.\n\nThat, according to Liverpool boss Klopp, is the only reason why he has been absent from the Premier League game against Watford and Champions League play-off with Hoffenheim.\n\nCoutinho last played for Liverpool in the Audi Cup pre-season game against Bayern Munich.\n\nLiverpool have removed Coutinho posters\n\nFootage posted on Twitter has showed a member of staff taking down the giant image of Coutinho from the front window of the official Liverpool store in the city centre's Williamson Square.\n\nHowever, it seems the reason for the window display was something more mundane.\n\nThe Liverpool Echo reports that ALL players, plus manager Klopp, were taken down in preparation for their Autumn fashion launch which begins on Monday.\n\nSo it's probably best wait to see if Coutinho is included in that launch before jumping to any conclusions.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now THE RUMOURS... Coutinho could sacrifice Brazil World Cup place\n\nIt has been suggested that Coutinho is so intent on leaving the club, he is even willing to risk his place in Brazil's squad for next summer's World Cup.\n\nMundo Deportivo reports that Coutinho is ready to sit in the stands for the remainder of the season if the club do not agree to his departure.\n\nWhile he believes that he has acted professionally throughout the summer, he is reportedly ready to ramp up his efforts to secure the move and put the pressure on Liverpool.\n\nBarca are struggling to land alternatives\n\nBarcelona have been knocked back by Napoli after bidding \u00a355m (\u20ac60m) for Lorenzo Insigne.\n\nLiverpool had considered the Italy international as a potential replacement for Coutinho, if he departs.\n\nThat has put the Blaugrana head-to-head with the Reds for Insigne, report Gazzetta dello Sport .\n\nWhile they are still clearly keen on Coutinho and Dembele, Barca are clearly looking at other alternatives with just two weeks of the window remaining.\n\nEl Clasico defeat could accelerate Barca's movements\n\nThe El Clasico defeat to Real Madrid in the Spanish Super Cup has reportedly put new life into Barca's exploits.\n\nThe 5-1 aggregate reverse against Real looks set to force them into accelerating their transfer business, with added emphasis on the Coutinho and Dembele deals.\n\nSport claim that club officials were so disappointed with the nature of the defeat that they were prepared to go all out in securing the necessary additions.\n\nIf Coutinho does leave...\n\nJurgen Klopp has lined up German star Max Meyer to replace Coutinho, should Liverpool cave in to Barcelona's demands.\n\nA \u00a360m move for Lorenzo Insigne is the first target, though the 21-year-old German attacking midfielder has been a long-term target.\n\nThe Germany international rejected a contract offer to stay at Schalke and only has a year left on his contract.\n\nAnd sources close to the highly-talented German star suggest he'd be open to teaming up with Klopp who tried to sign him as a teenager when the Kop boss managed Borussia Dortmund.\n\npoll loading Will AP\n\nSporting director Robert Fernandez was less emphatic when asked about the deals later, although he was optimistic that both will soon be Barcelona players.\n\n\"Dembele and Coutinho are two important players that we like a lot and have done for a long time,\" said Fernandez at the unveiling of Brazil midfielder Paulinho, a \u00a336.4 million signing from Chinese club Guangzhou Evergrande.\n\n\"They have the conditions, the age and could adapt to our football. They would be good to have here. That's the reality.\"\n\nUnder pressure to spend big after pocketing a world record 222 million euros from Paris Saint-Germain for Neymar, Barcelona have already had a \u00a390 million bid for 25-year-old Brazilian attacking midfielder Coutinho rejected by Liverpool.\n\nSpanish media have also reported that Barcelona are prepared to pay an initial 80 million euros, plus 40 million in bonuses, to Borussia Dortmund for 20-year-old French winger Dembele.\n\nFernandez added: \"With respect to Liverpool and Dortmund, when there are negotiations you need time, you need to work things into a favourable situation for players and ourselves.\n\n\"We still have days ahead of us, would like to move things faster, but (I) do admit they're two players we would like here. But it's the clubs who will have the final say on if we finally achieve those two transfers.\"\n\nLiverpool and Dortmund have both been adamant that their respective players are not for sale, with the Premier League club's manager Jurgen Klopp insisting that no discussions are ongoing with Barcelona.\n\n\"No news from me because no-one told me anything different since we spoke last time about this,\" said Klopp on Thursday.\n\nSuarez sidelined\n\nCoutinho, currently sidelined with a back injury, last week handed in a transfer request that was turned down by Liverpool's American owners.\n\nThere have been suggestions Coutinho could agitate for a move by effectively going on strike, but while he is still injured that is impossible.\n\nKlopp conceded it is a tricky situation for all parties, but was keen not to be seen criticising the Brazilian's attitude.\n\n\"To be honest I have nothing to say about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he has obviously not been in training,\" he said.\n\nIn contrast to Coutinho, Dembele has been suspended indefinitely by Dortmund after skipping training in a personal protest to pressure the German club to sell him.\n\nHe will not play in his current side's opening Bundesliga game against Wolfsburg this weekend but Dortmund CEO Hans-Joachim Watzke on Thursday rubbished the claims made by Segura.\n\n\"Barcelona have not managed to fulfil their wish to complete Dembele's transfer -- until now, they aren't one-millimetre closer,\" Watzke told German magazine Kicker.\n\nDembele, 20, was signed from Rennes just last year and has a contract until 2021.\n\nBarcelona are eager to complete the signings with their opening game of the season in La Liga coming at home to Betis on Sunday.\n\nThe 2-0 defeat to Madrid on Wednesday saw them lose the Spanish Super Cup 5-1 on aggregate and also saw them lose Luis Suarez to injury.\n\nThe Uruguayan striker suffered a knee injury in the game that means he will be out for around a month, ruling him out of Barca's first three league games and their first Champions League group match.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 17, 2017 10:44 pm | Two Barcelona offers - the second of \u00a390million - have been rejected.\n\nThus, in a bid to force a move Coutinho has handed in a transfer request at Anfield. And Ayestaran believes \"he ticks all the boxes\" for the Catalan club.\n\n\"Barca simply need a player like Coutinho, both tactically and for his quality. From a tactical point of view, I think he is a perfect fit,\" Ayestaran told The Independent.\n\n\"They have already lost Xavi while Andres Iniesta is already in the latter stages of his career so will play less, and they thereby don't manage to control the ball in the middle of the pitch in the same way, or make it arrive for the forwards at the right pace. They have lost that. Coutinho can offer this, he ticks all the boxes, and especially those penetrating passes.\n\n\"Liverpool's game last year was all about attackers alternating positions so much, and it was often down to Coutinho to choose the right tempo of the play. He is also probably a better positional player than a player on the break, as he gives the right angles for passing options, his body shape is good, and he always chooses the right option.\"\n\nLiverpool have so far rejected two offers from the Spanish side for the Brazil international and continue to insist that he is going nowhere.\n\nBarcelona general manager Pep Segura declared on Wednesday night that a deal was 'close' for Coutinho, and also Ousmane Dembele.\n\n\"We are close to Coutinho and Dembele, we are discussing their conditions but we do not know when they will be sealed,\" said Segura.\n\nDortmund have laughed off that suggestion regarding the Frenchman while Liverpool have similarly distanced themselves from Segura's claim.\n\nReds boss Jurgen Klopp, speaking on Thursday, said there was \"nothing new\" regarding a potential departure.\n\npoll loading Will Philippe Coutinho still be a Liverpool player on September 1? 44000+ VOTES SO FAR YES NO", They would be good to have here. That's the reality.\"\n\nUnder pressure to spend big after pocketing a world record 222 million euros from Paris Saint-Germain for Neymar, Barcelona have already had a \u00a390 million bid for 25-year-old Brazilian attacking midfielder Coutinho rejected by Liverpool.\n\nSpanish media have also reported that Barcelona are prepared to pay an initial 80 million euros, plus 40 million in bonuses, to Borussia Dortmund for 20-year-old French winger Dembele.\n\nFernandez added: \"With respect to Liverpool and Dortmund, when there are negotiations you need time, you need to work things into a favourable situation for players and ourselves.\n\n\"We still have days ahead of us, would like to move things faster, but (I) do admit they're two players we would like here. But it's the clubs who will have the final say on if we finally achieve those two transfers.\"\n\nLiverpool and Dortmund have both been adamant that their respective players are not for sale, with the Premier League club's manager Jurgen Klopp insisting that no discussions are ongoing with Barcelona.\n\n\"No news from me because no-one told me anything different since we spoke last time about this,\" said Klopp on Thursday.\n\n- Suarez sidelined -\n\nCoutinho, currently sidelined with a back injury, last week handed in a transfer request that was turned down by Liverpool's American owners.\n\nThere have been suggestions Coutinho could agitate for a move by effectively going on strike, but while he is still injured that is impossible.\n\nKlopp conceded it is a tricky situation for all parties, but was keen not to be seen criticising the Brazilian's attitude.\n\n\"To be honest I have nothing to say about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he has obviously not been in training,\" he said.\n\nIn contrast to Coutinho, Dembele has been suspended indefinitely by Dortmund after skipping training in a personal protest to pressure the German club to sell him.\n\nHe will not play in his current side's opening Bundesliga game against Wolfsburg this weekend but Dortmund CEO Hans-Joachim Watzke on Thursday rubbished the claims made by Segura.\n\n\"Barcelona have not managed to fulfil their wish to complete Dembele's transfer -- until now, they aren't one millimetre closer,\" Watzke told German magazine Kicker.\n\nDembele, 20, was signed from Rennes just last year and has a contract until 2021.\n\nBarcelona are eager to complete the signings with their opening game of the season in La Liga coming at home to Betis on Sunday.\n\nThe 2-0 defeat to Madrid on Wednesday saw them lose the Spanish Super Cup 5-1 on aggregate and also saw them lose Luis Suarez to injury.\n\nThe Uruguayan striker suffered a knee injury in the game that means he will be out for around a month, ruling him out of Barca's first three league games and their first Champions League group match.\n\nShares", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T17:05:00Z", transfer window shuts.\n\nLiverpool have remained adamant that Brazilian playmaker Coutinho - who has submitted a transfer request - will not be sold in this transfer window, with both manager Jurgen not least following the shocking 5-1 defeat on aggregate to Real Madrid in the Spanish Super Cup.\n\nThe club are reeling, still, from Neymar's world record \u00a3198million switch to Paris Saint-Germain and want Coutinho and Borussia Dortmund's Ousmane Dembele, for a similar fee to the one offered for Coutinho, to appease supporters.\n\nOn Thursday they presented former Tottenham Hotspur midfielder Paulinho following his \u00a336.4million switch from Chinese club Guangzhou Evergrande but bigger signings are desperately needed.\n\nBarcelona have also suffered the blow of Luis Suarez being ruled out injured for four to five weeks with a knee injury while Gerard Pique stated that he felt \"inferior\" to Real for the first time in nearly a decade.\n\nWhen questioned about whether Barcelona was a good move for Coutinho at present given their problems, Klopp dwelt on his own club's positives.\n\n\"Can you imagine for a minute, I am not a little bit interested about the problems or not of Barcelona,\" he said. \"I don't see a lot of reasons for each player to leave Liverpool at the moment and that's just in general.\n\n\"I think for each player Liverpool is a very good club, a very good team in the moment.\n\n\"We have a good age of the group. We have very young boys, experience - it's a good mix and we are on our way. I am very positive about the project of Liverpool.\"\n\nCoutinho was moved into a more central midfield role last season by Klopp as the German sought to build his team around the player.\n\nThe 25-year-old is currently struggling with back injury which is set to keep him out of Liverpool's Premier League fixture against Crystal Palace on Saturday.\n\nHowever, Klopp insists Liverpool can change their system and approach in Coutinho's absence.\n\n\"Every team in the world would miss a creative player in whichever position of his quality,\" added the German. \"Having Phil not available was never cool but it happened. {"id": "9736508", "categories": [{"id": 51, "label": "dmoz/Games/Video Games/Recreation", "uri": "dmoz/Games/Video_Games/Recreation", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 751, "label": "dmoz/Games/Board Games/Abstract", "uri": "dmoz/Games/Board_Games/Abstract", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 822, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian Rules", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian_Rules", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711002925", "source": {"id": "2237", "title": "Vanguard", "uri": "vanguardngr.com"}, "url": "http://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/08/barcelona-hopeful-coutinho-dembele-deals/", "body": "Barcelona are hopeful of pushing through deals to sign both Ousmane Dembele and Philippe Coutinho in the coming days as efforts to fill the gap left by the departed Neymar intensify.\n\nThe Spanish club's general manager Pep Segura, speaking early on Thursday morning after the Spanish Super Cup defeat to Real Madrid, indicated that the transfers were \"close\" to being completed.\n\nSporting director Robert Fernandez was less emphatic when asked about the deals later, although he was optimistic that both will soon be Barcelona players.\n\n\"Dembele and Coutinho are two important players that we like a lot and have done for a long time,\" said Fernandez at the unveiling of Brazil midfielder Paulinho, a 40 million-euro ($47 million, \u00a336.4 million) signing from Chinese club Guangzhou Evergrande.\n\n\"They have the conditions, the age and could adapt to our football. They would be good to have here. That's the reality.\"\n\nUnder pressure to spend big after pocketing a world record 222 million euros from Paris Saint-Germain for Neymar, Barcelona have already had a \u00a390 million bid for 25-year-old Brazilian attacking midfielder Coutinho rejected by Liverpool.\n\nSpanish media have also reported that Barcelona are prepared to pay an initial 80 million euros, plus 40 million in bonuses, to Borussia Dortmund for 20-year-old French winger Dembele.\n\nFernandez added: \"With respect to Liverpool and Dortmund, when there are negotiations you need time, you need to work things into a favourable situation for players and ourselves.\n\n\"We still have days ahead of us, would like to move things faster, but (I) do admit they're two players we would like here. But it's the clubs who will have the final say on if we finally achieve those two transfers.\"\n\nLiverpool and Dortmund have both been adamant that their respective players are not for sale, with the Premier League club's manager Jurgen Klopp insisting that no discussions are ongoing with Barcelona.\n\n\"No news from me because no-one told me anything different since we spoke last time about this,\" said Klopp on Thursday.\n\n- Suarez sidelined -\n\nCoutinho, currently sidelined with a back injury, last week handed in a transfer request that was turned down by Liverpool's American owners.\n\nThere have been suggestions Coutinho could agitate for a move by effectively going on strike, but while he is still injured that is impossible.\n\nKlopp conceded it is a tricky situation for all parties, but was keen not to be seen criticising the Brazilian's attitude.\n\n\"To be honest I have nothing to say about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he has obviously not been in training,\" he said.\n\nIn contrast to Coutinho, Dembele has been suspended indefinitely by Dortmund after skipping training in a personal protest to pressure the German club to sell him.\n\nHe will not play in his current side's opening Bundesliga game against Wolfsburg this weekend but Dortmund CEO Hans-Joachim Watzke on Thursday rubbished the claims made by Segura.\n\n\"Barcelona have not managed to fulfil their wish to complete Dembele's transfer -- until now, they aren't one millimetre closer,\" Watzke told German magazine Kicker.\n\nDembele, 20, was signed from Rennes just last year and has a contract until 2021.\n\nBarcelona are eager to complete the signings with their opening game of the season in La Liga coming at home to Betis on Sunday.\n\nThe 2-0 defeat to Madrid on Wednesday saw them lose the Spanish Super Cup 5-1 on aggregate and also saw them lose Luis Suarez to injury.\n\nThe Uruguayan striker suffered a knee injury in the game that means he will be out for around a month, ruling him out of Barca's first three league games and their first Champions League group match.", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T16:47:00Z", {"id": "9607979", "categories": [{"id": 99, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Signage", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Signage", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710669534", "source": {"id": "492", "title": "Daily News and Analysis (DNA) India", "uri": "dnaindia.com"}, "url": "http://www.dnaindia.com/sports/report-barcelona-close-to-signing-liverpool-s-philippe-coutinho-and-dortmund-s-ousmane-dembele-2532518", "body": "According to reports in British media, Coutinho has submitted a transfer request after Liverpool rejected a second bid worth 100 million euros from the La Liga club.\n\nBarcelona sporting manager Pep Segura has said the club are \"close\" to signing Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele from Borussia Dortmund.\n\nSpeaking after Wednesday's 2-0 defeat to Real Madrid in the second leg of the Spanish Super Cup gave their arch rivals a 5-1 aggregate victory, Segura said Barcelona were discussing terms with the attacking duo.\n\n\"We are close to Coutinho and Dembele, we are discussing their conditions but we do not know when they will be sealed,\" Segura told Spanish television station TV3. \"We hope they will be Barcelona players this season.\"\n\nBarcelona, who said on Monday they had agreed a deal to sign Brazilian midfielder Paulinho for 40 million euros ($47.19 million), are looking to fill the void left by Neymar after his world record 222 million euros transfer to Paris St Germain. According to reports in British media, Coutinho has submitted a transfer request after Liverpool rejected a second bid worth 100 million euros from the La Liga club.\n\nBarcelona's other reported target, Dembele, has been suspended by Borussia Dortmund after the 20-year-old France international skipped training amid speculation of a possible move to Spain. An initial Barca offer was rejected by Dortmund, with club bosses saying it was too low. German media have estimated the price of a move at more than 100 million euros.\n\nBarcelona are clearly in need of reinforcements after being outclassed in the Super Cup. Nothing to say from our side,\" said the Reds boss.\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they are saying; I don't even know them - especially this guy, I've never even met him.\"\n\nAsked whether there had been any subsequent talks Klopp added: \"I am not sure I have to answer this only because we have said what we have to say, or the club said what we have to say.\n\n\"No news from me because no-one told me anything different since we spoke last time about this.\"\n\nThere have been suggestions Coutinho could agitate for a move by effectively going on strike but while he is still injured that is impossible.\n\nKlopp was asked about the prospect of this and the Brazil international's general attitude.\n\n\"To be honest I have nothing to say about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he has obviously not been in training,\" he said.\n\n\"I asked the medical department how he is doing and there are no complaints so that is how it is. There is nothing bad to say about this.\n\n\"We are all not silly. We know it is a very difficult situation but there is nothing new to say.\n\n\"It is not always easy for me to say the 100% truth - even though I don't like to like - but it is exactly how I say it {"id": "9792786", "categories": [{"id": 14, "label": "dmoz/Sports", "uri": "dmoz/Sports", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 673, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/AFC", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/AFC", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 822, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian Rules", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian_Rules", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711158124", "source": {"id": "1228", "title": "Herald Sun", "uri": "heraldsun.com.au"}, "url": "http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/football/barcelona-transfer-news-philippe-coutinho-ousmane-dembele-liverpool-borussia-dortmund-manuel-lanzini/news-story/711e4cec527cba4475f34cc16f369291", "body": "BARCELONA are still after Liverpool playmaker Philippe Coutinho and Borussia Dortmund forward Ousmane Dembele.\n\nCoutinho put in a transfer request last week, but Liverpool has said that he is not for sale after rejecting two offers for the Brazil international from Barcelona.\n\nDembele has been fined and suspended from team training by Dortmund, and is reportedly refused all contact with the club since Barcelona made a bid reported to be worth 105 million euros ($124 million), including add-ons.\n\n\"I recognize that they are two players that we really want to come, but their clubs are the ones who have to decide if we can make these signings,\" Barcelona sporting director Robert Fernandez said Thursday.\n\nLiverpool could have an ace up their sleeve thanks to the fact they don't have a release clause in the Brazilian's contract. Fernandez added that the club had been hampered because Liverpool did not have a buy-out clause in Coutinho's deal.\n\n\"Not just Barca but any team looking for top quality players are getting involved in a very difficult situation in this market,\" he said.\n\n\"Why? Because the market is where clubs like us want to sign top quality players. There's no buy-out clauses so that makes things trickier.\n\n\"Yes, we are negotiating with clubs to make several signings, but in all awareness of the difficulty. We need to work our way into a favourable situation and hopefully close these deals as quickly as possible.\n\n\"Dembele and Coutinho are two important players that we like a lot and have done for a long time. They have the conditions, the right age and could adapt to our football. They would be good to have here. That's the reality.\n\n\"With respect to Liverpool and Dortmund, when there are negotiations you need time, you need to work things into a favourable situation for players and ourselves.\n\n\"We still have days ahead of us, would like to move things faster, but do admit they're two players we would like here. But it's the clubs who will have the final say on if we finally achieve those two transfers.\"\n\nThose comments come after the Catalan club's general manager, Josep Segura, told TV3: \" We are discussing the conditions of Coutinho and Dembele. We are close, obviously, but as long as we don't have the deal closed, we cannot say anything.\"\n\nWhen asked if he believed if the pair would both move to Barcelona this summer, Segura replied: \"We hope.\"\n\nBarcelona is trying to reinvest the 222 million euros ($262 million) it received from Paris Saint-Germain when the French club signed Brazil striker Neymar.\n\nChallenge your mates in Fox Sports Premier League Fantasy, and you could win FREE FOXTEL. Select your team now!\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they're saying. I don't even know him. I have never met him,\" Klopp said, referring to Segura.\n\n\"We have already said what we have to say. [There is] no news from me. Nobody told me anything different since we spoke last time.\"\n\nWhen asked if Coutinho's absence against Crystal Palace was due to his back injury, Klopp replied: \"I think so. I've not been told any different.\n\n\"That is always how it is with injured players. I don't know when he will be back. There's nothing new.\"\n\nReports in the Spanish press have suggested Coutinho would be willing to go on strike in order to push through a move to the Nou Camp.\n\nKlopp insists the Brazilian has remained professional despite the ongoing transfer speculation, although he admits he has not spoke with the 25-year-old since he suffered his back injury.\n\n\"To be honest there is nothing I can say about his attitude because since he has the back problems he's not been in training,\" Klopp said.\n\n\"But when I asked the medical department how he is doing, there was no complaints. That's how it is. There's nothing bad to say.\"\n\nOne of the contingencies linked with Liverpool has been West Ham's Manuel Lanzini.\n\nBut Hammers boss Slaven Bilic has said: \"I speak to Manu every day. He is very happy, he feels at home here and he feels wanted.\n\n\"You can feel it, you can see it. I don't have to talk to him. You see how he is smiling here.\"\n\nThe West Ham boss believes playing regularly for West Ham in a World Cup year means Lanzini is happy to stay in east London.\n\n\"He broke into the national team of Argentina despite being injured, he got a call up for the September games. So he knows if he is playing here for West Ham and has a good season, he can improve, sign a better contract with West Ham and play for Argentina,\" said Bilic.\n\nMeanwhile, club legend Phil Thompson has told the club to hang onto Coutinho this window - but - make sure contingencies are being plotted to ease the transition when he goes.\n\nHe told Sky Sports: \"The ideal resolution is that the club will leave it very late and get as much as they can for him. If he doesn't want to stay then I'd rather see him sold for the best price, but the big issue is that there won't be any players near is quality on the market.\n\n\"It's probably too late in the window to get somebody in, so I think they'll keep him for a season. Coutinho might argue that Barcelona won't be there again but if you believe you're a top player then a top club will always be interested.\n\n\"I think the owners will hold firm. They've backed themselves into a corner with the statements they've made along with Jurgen Klopp's comments, so I just don't see how they can go back on that, especially when the fans are already quite unhappy with the summer transfer business as deals for Virgil van Dijk and Naby Keita are looking increasingly unlikely.\n\n\"The comments coming out from Barca saying that a deal is close might be a red flag to a bull, making the owners, who are adamant because of the deal they gave him six months ago, even more focused on standing their ground, so I think they will keep him.\"\n\nHe added: \"What they can do is try to find somebody out there, maybe even play Barcelona at their own game and say you can have Coutinho but we want Luis Suarez.\n\n\"Suarez might be unhappy with the Neymar situation. You don't know whether a player is unhappy or a club are willing to sell until you ask the question.\n\n\"They could go after Dele Alli, who was a Liverpool supporter as a kid. Tottenham are a bit like Liverpool in that there's always a price on a player.\n\n\"Sergio Aguero is another player that might be interested if he's not happy at Manchester City, but it comes back to being late in the window and that is the difficult situation Liverpool find themselves in.\n\n\"Signing Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain would be a start and would be available for the right money with his contract situation at Arsenal, but the club need to be ready to move if they do sell so we're not caught short.\"\n\nSo far, Barcelona has been limited to convincing Chinese club Guangzhou Evergrande to part with Brazil midfielder Paulinho for 40 million euros ($47 million).\n\nThe 29-year-old Paulinho signed a four-year contract on Thursday, three days before Barcelona opens the Spanish league season against Real Betis.\n\nPaulinho was considered a disappointment when he played for English club Tottenham for two seasons before moving to Guangzhou in 2015.\n\nHe said at his presentation at Camp Nou that he had recovered his confidence in China.\n\n\"My first season in Tottenham was very good. In the second I couldn't play consistently,\" Paulinho said. \"Perhaps it wasn't my best season. Things didn't go as I would have liked. But that is the past. I accepted the challenge of playing in China and I won back both my desire and confidence there.\"\n\nPaulinho will be tasked with strengthening a Barcelona midfield that took a step back last season, a decline that stopped it from defending its Spanish league title.\n\nRead more at Sky Sports UK\n\nOriginally published as Ace that could save Reds, Klopp hits back at Barca", "dateTime": We're close [to Coutinho and Dembele], we're talking about the conditions but until everything is finalised, we can't say anything else. We hope they will wear a Barca shirt.\"\n\nBarcelona midfielder Sergio Busquets reiterated his calls for fresh signings following the heavy defeat to Madrid on Wednesday night.\n\n\"It's clear signings are needed,\" Busquets said. \"We have to strengthen the squad. We need attacking players to compensate for Neymar.\n\n\"But every position can be strengthened and the more quality players that come in the better. I hope the best players arrive and that they generate competition and give the coach decisions to make.\"\n\nAlso See: Mignolet backs attacking style Liverpool grab first-leg lead 'Everyone wants 'I don't know why other people are saying what they are saying; I don't even know them - especially this guy, I've never even met him.'\n\nJurgen Klopp has hit back at Barcelona general manager Pep Segura over Philippe Coutinho\n\nSegura had claimed that Barca were close to completing a deal to sign the Reds playmaker\n\nLiverpool are adamant they will be keeping Coutinho, who has submitted a transfer request.\n\nBut Segura suggested that will not be the case.\n\n'We are close to Coutinho and Dembele,' he said on Catalan television station TV3. 'We are discussing their deals but do not know when it will be done.'\n\nKlopp, who revealed that Daniel Sturridge was in contention to face Crystal Palace at Anfield this weekend, begged to differ when asked if there had been talks.\n\n'I am not sure I have to answer this only because we only said what we have to say, or the club said what we have to say,' he said.\n\n'Nothing to say. No news from me because no-one told me anything different since we spoke last time about this.'\n\nKlopp insists there is nothing new to say on Coutinho, who is currently out with a back injury\n\nThe Liverpool manager suggested that there may be an element of smoke and mirrors surrounding the Coutinho situation.\n\n'We are all not silly,' he said. 'We know it is a very difficult situation but there is nothing new to say.\n\n'It is not always easy for me to say the 100 per cent truth - even though I don't like to lie - but it is exactly how I say it because that is how it is in the moment, nothing else.'\n\nCoutinho is currently out with a back injury, with no time-frame set for his return.\n\nKlopp said there were no issues over his attitude.\n\nKlopp claims that there is nothing wrong with Coutinho's attitude, despite his transfer request\n\n'To be honest I have nothing to say about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he has obviously not been in training,' Klopp said.\n\n'I asked the medical department how he is doing and there are no complaints so that is how it is. There is nothing bad to say about this. We are all not silly. We know it is a very difficult situation but there is nothing new to say.\n\n'It is not always easy for me to say the 100 per cent truth - even though I don't like to like - but it is exactly how I say it because that is how it is in the moment, nothing else.'\n\nWith regards to strengthening his own squad, Klopp confirmed that Liverpool are actively chasing targets.\n\nMeanwhile, Reds striker Daniel Sturridge is in contention to face Crystal Palace this weekend\n\n'We are looking but that is what I do when I am not actually on the pitch or not thinking about training or the next game,' Klopp explained.' Of course we think about what we can do.\n\n'But if the transfer window would have ended yesterday we already would have a team which I like and could play football with.\n\n'Of course, injuries here and there are not too cool but in this moment it is still a good team.'\n\nKlopp believes a hunt for fresh talent could go to the final day.\n\n'We will see what happens,' he said. 'I cannot change the answer because I don't know.\n\n'It is nothing like \"There is a contract, sign it\", a few things can happen on both sides but everything leads in the direction of August 31 and I can imagine it will be a busy day. {"id": "9624134", "categories": [{"id": 533, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Camps", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Camps", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 534, "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Camps/North America", "uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Camps/North_America", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 644, "label": "dmoz/Business/Transportation and Logistics/Moving Services", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Transportation_and_Logistics/Moving_Services", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710713802", "source": {"id": "713", "title": "International Business Times UK", "uri": "ibtimes.co.uk"}, "url": "http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/barcelona-general-manager-confirms-imminent-deals-philippe-coutinho-ousmane-dembele-1635370", "body": "Both players are ready to force moves to the Camp Nou this summer.\n\nBarcelona are close to completing their fifth and sixth signing of the summer after the Catalan club's general manager Pep Segura confirmed that deals for Ousmane Dembele and Philippe Coutinho are close. The former Liverpool academy technical manager was speaking after the club's 5-1 aggregate loss to Real Madrid in the Spanish Super Cup on Wednesday (16 August).\n\nThe La Liga side have thus far made four additions to the squad - Nelson Semedo, Gerard Deulofeu, Marlon Santos and Paulinho. But they lost a key player in Neymar, who joined Paris Saint-Germain in a world-record \u20ac222m (\u00a3198m) deal.\n\nBarcelona are now looking at alternatives to fill the void left by the Brazilian and have identified Dembele as the perfect replacement and have made contact with his current employers Borussia Dortmund about a move this summer. The German club have rejected the Spanish outfit's opening bid but are willing to sanction a move if their valuation of around \u20ac150m is met.\n\nThe Camp Nou outfit are said to have returned with an improved second bid and agreed a base fee of \u20ac100m (\u00a390.8m) but are yet to agree on the performance based add-ons with Dortmund asking for around \u20ac30m. Dembele is keen to move and is trying to force a move by skipping training, which has earned him a suspension.\n\nCoutinho, on the other hand, has been on Barcelona's radar since last season and a move for the Brazilian was planned before Neymar's departure. The La Liga club views the Liverpool midfielder as a long-term replacement for Andres Iniesta, who is in the final year of his contract.\n\nBarcelona have had a bid for Coutinho rejected by the Premier League side, and the Reds have made it clear that he is not for sale. But the former Inter Milan midfielder is keen on a move and has handed in a transfer request to force through a move to the Camp Nou this summer. The Spanish giants remain confident that they can reach an agreement with Liverpool.\n\n\"Coutinho and Dembele are both close. We are hopeful that they will end up wearing the Barca shirt,\" Segura said in the aftermath of Barcelona's disappointing loss to Real on Wednesday (16 August), as quoted by Goal.\n\n\"Until deals are closed I can't say anything. We know we have to help the team and reinforce it and that's what we are doing,\" the Barcelona general manager added.\n\nBarcelona manager Ernesto Valverde, meanwhile, was unsure if the deals for Dembele and Coutinho will be completed before the start of the La Liga season on 18 August. The Catalan club take on Real Betis in their opening game on Sunday (20 August).\n\n\"I don't know,\" was Valverde's response to the question about deals for Dembele and Coutinho being completed, as 'I don't see a lot of reasons for each player to leave the club at the moment.' Klopp, whose side host Crystal Palace on Saturday, admitted that it was a blow to be without Coutinho's ability.\n\n'Every team in the world would miss a creative player in whichever position of his quality,' he said. 'That's not too cool but I am already used to it...that's how football works.'\n\nEarlier this week, Barcelona general manager Pep Segura said a deal for Coutinho, who Liverpool's owners have said will not be leaving the club in this window, was 'close' but Klopp believes that is not the case.\n\nLiverpool boss Jurgen Klopp has said the situation surrounding the Brazilian star is 'not cool'\n\n'I don't know why other people are saying what they are saying,' he said. 'I don't even know them - especially this guy, I've never even met him.'\n\nKlopp added that the saga was not easy to deal with. 'We are all not silly,' he said. 'We know it is a very difficult situation but there is nothing new to say. It is not always easy for me to say the 100 per cent truth - even though I don't like to lie - but it is exactly how I say it because that is how it is in the moment, nothing else.'\n\nWith regards to strengthening his squad, Klopp confirmed that Liverpool are actively chasing targets and said that if injury struck it was not big enough.\n\n'Of course we think about what we can do,' he added. 'But if the transfer window would have ended yesterday we already would have a team which I like and could play football with. Of course, injuries here and there are not too cool but in this moment it is still a good team.'\n\nBarcelona target Coutinho may be kept against his wishes by Liverpool this summer", "dateTime": at the Camp Nou in time to feature in their opening La Liga fixture against Real Betis.\n\nAsked whether the deals could be done in time for Sunday, Valverde replied: 'I don't know'.\n\nLiverpool have {"id": "9613257", "categories": [], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710685371", "source": {"id": "186", "title": "Sify", "uri": "sify.com"}, "url": "http://www.sify.com/finance/soccer-barca-close-to-coutinho-dembele-deals-segura-news-football-rirjdsahadbge.html", "body": "MADRID: Barcelona sporting manager Pep Segura has said the club are \"close\" to signing Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele from Borussia Dortmund.\n\nSpeaking after Wednesday's 2-0 defeat to Real Madrid in the second leg of the Spanish Super Cup gave their arch rivals a 5-1 aggregate victory, Segura said Barcelona were discussing terms with the attacking duo.\n\n\"We are close to Coutinho and Dembele, we are discussing their conditions but we do not know when they will be sealed,\" Segura told Spanish television station TV3. \"We hope they will be Barcelona players this season.\"\n\nBarcelona, who said on Monday they had agreed a deal to sign Brazilian midfielder Paulinho for 40 million euros ($47.19 million), are looking to fill the void left by Neymar after his world record 222 million euros transfer to Paris St Germain.\n\nAccording to reports in British media, Coutinho has submitted a transfer request after Liverpool rejected a second bid worth 100 million euros from the La Liga club.\n\nBarcelona's other reported target, Dembele, has been suspended by Borussia Dortmund after the 20-year-old France international skipped training amid speculation of a possible move to Spain.\n\nAn initial Barca offer was rejected by Dortmund, with club bosses saying it was too low. German media have estimated the price of a move at more than 100 million euros.\n\nBarcelona are clearly in need of reinforcements after being outclassed in the Super Cup. After losing 3-1 at home on Sunday, Wednesday's 2-0 defeat came at the hands of a Madrid side minus Cristiano Ronaldo, Gareth Bale and Isco.\n\nSEARCH", "dateTime": "2017-08-17T05:04:00Z", Nothing to say from our side,\" Klopp told reporters on Thursday.\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they are saying; I don't even know them -- especially this guy, I've never even met him.\"\n\nQuizzed on whether there had been any recent talks at all, Klopp added: \"I am not sure I have to answer this only because we have said what we have to say, or the club said what we have to say.\n\n\"No news from me because no-one told me anything different since we spoke last time about this.\"\n\nThere have been suggestions Coutinho could agitate for a move by effectively going on strike, but while he is still injured that is impossible.\n\nKlopp conceded it is a tricky situation for all parties, but was keen not to be seen criticising the Brazilian's attitude.\n\n\"To be honest I have nothing to say about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he has obviously not been in training,\" he said.\n\n\"I asked the medical department how he is doing and there are no complaints so that is how it is. Nothing to say from our side,\" Klopp told reporters on Thursday.\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they are saying; I don't even know them -- especially this guy, I've never even met him.\"\n\nQuizzed on whether there had been any recent talks at all, Klopp added: \"I am not sure I have to answer this only because we have said what we have to say, or the club said what we have to say.\n\n\"No news from me because no-one told me anything different since we spoke last time about this.\"\n\nThere have been suggestions Coutinho could agitate for a move by effectively going on strike, but while he is still injured that is impossible.\n\nKlopp conceded it is a tricky situation for all parties, but was keen not to be seen criticising the Brazilian's attitude.\n\n\"To be honest I have nothing to say about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he has obviously not been in training,\" he said.\n\n\"I asked the medical department how he is doing and there are no complaints so that is how it is. Nothing to say from our side,\" said the Reds boss.\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they are saying; I don't even know them - especially this guy, I've never even met him.\"\n\nAsked whether there had been any subsequent talks Klopp added: \"I am not sure I have to answer this only because we have said what we have to say, or the club said what we have to say.\n\n\"No news from me because no-one told me anything different since we spoke last time about this.\"\n\nThere have been suggestions Coutinho could agitate for a move by effectively going on strike but while he is still injured that is impossible.\n\nKlopp was asked about the prospect of this and the Brazil international's general attitude.\n\n\"To be honest I have nothing to say about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he has obviously not been in training,\" he said.\n\n\"I asked the medical department how he is doing and there are no complaints so that is how it is. There is nothing bad to say about this.\n\n\"We are all not silly. German media have estimated the price of a move at more than 100 million euros.\n\nBarcelona are clearly in need of reinforcements after being outclassed in the Super Cup. After losing 3-1 at home on Sunday, Wednesday's 2-0 defeat came at the hands of a Madrid side minus Cristiano Ronaldo, Gareth Bale and Isco.\n\n(Editing by Peter Rutherford)\n\nGet latest news & live It is true and I recognise this, that they are two players (Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele) we feel like bringing here.\"\n\n\"Dembele and Coutinho are two important players that we like a lot and have done for a long time. Not as a team or as a club,\" said Pique. \"We have to stick together and move forward.\n\n\"The season is long and it has just begun. {"id": "9844088", "categories": [{"id": 99, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Signage", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Signage", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711314331", "source": {"id": "686", "title": "Daily Record & Sunday Mail", "uri": "dailyrecord.co.uk"}, "url": "http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/sport/football/football-transfer-news/barcelona-admit-philippe-coutinho-deal-11008094", "body": "The Catalan giants had previously claimed a move for the Brazilian was close.\n\nGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nBarcelona sporting director Robert Fernandez has admitted they face a struggle to sign Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho because he does not have a release clause.\n\nKop boss Jurgen Klopp has steeled himself for a third bid for the 25-year-old after the Reds rejected \u00a372million and \u00a390million offers from the Catalans, report the Liverpool Echo.\n\nThe English Premier League side are digging their heels in over the Brazilian though and remain adamant they will not sell him this summer, despite the fact he submitted a transfer request last week.\n\nThis comes after Barcelona general manager Pep Segura was quoted as saying the La Liga side were \"close\" to securing a deal, but Fernandez was less optimistic as he spoke about a \"very difficult situation\".\n\nBarca, who completed the signing of Paulinho on Thursday, want to spend their \u00a3200million windfall from the sale of Neymar on deals for Coutinho and Borussia Dortmund's Ousmane Dembele.\n\n\"Not just Barca but any team looking for top quality players are getting involved in a very difficult situation in this market,\" Fernandez said.\n\n\"Why? Because the market is where clubs like us want to sign top quality players. There's no buy-out clauses so that makes things trickier.\n\n\"Yes, we are negotiating with clubs to make several signings, but in all awareness of the difficulty. We need to work our way into a favourable situation and hopefully close these deals as quickly as possible.\n\n\"Dembele and Coutinho are two important players that we like a lot and have done for a long time. They have the conditions, the right age and could adapt to our football. They would be good to have here. That's the reality.\n\n\"With respect to Liverpool and Dortmund, when there are negotiations you need time, you need to work things into a favourable situation for players and ourselves.\n\n\"We still have days ahead of us, would like to move things faster, but do admit they're two players we would like here. But it's the clubs who will have the final say on if we finally achieve those two transfers.\"\n\nBarcelona's need for attacking reinforcements has been heightened by a knee injury to Luis Suarez in the Super Cup defeat to Real Madrid. {"id": "9681688", "categories": [{"id": 822, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian Rules", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian_Rules", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 1038, "label": "dmoz/Arts/Performing Arts/Magic", "uri": "dmoz/Arts/Performing_Arts/Magic", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710864859", "source": {"id": "709", "title": "Sky Sports", "uri": "skysports.com"}, "url": "http://www.skysports.com/football/news/12087/10992339/philippe-coutinho-deal-to-barcelona-not-as-close-as-many-people-think-says-guillem-balague", "body": "Guillem Balague\n\nSpanish Football Expert & Columnist @GuillemBalague\n\nPhilippe Coutinho deal to Barcelona not as close as many people think, says Guillem Balague\n\nLast Updated: 17/08/17 12:59pm\n\nGuillem Balague believes there are still plenty of hurdles to get through before Barcelona can sign Philippe Coutinho from Liverpool, if they are able at all.\n\nAccording to the Catalan club's general manager Josep Segura, Barcelona are close to agreeing deals for both Coutinho and Borussia Dortmund's Ousmane Dembele.\n\nSegura told TV3 that the club were \"close\" to negotiating details for the pair, but will remain tight-lipped until anything is finalised.\n\nBarcelona vs Real Betis\n\nAugust 20, 2017, 7:10pm\n\nLive on\n\nGet Sky Sports Get a Sky Sports pass\n\nBalague said: \"This is exactly what Segura said: 'We are negotiating the details for Coutinho and Dembele. We are close, that is obvious, but until everything gets fully confirmed, you cannot say anything else.'\n\n\"Reading between the lines, he is trying to say - and I have spoken to all the relevant sources - that Barca want both players and they are in talks with their representatives. Not more than that. Even though if you take a sentence from it out of context it sounds different.\n\n\"It means they still need to do deals with the clubs and that will not be easy, in fact, it is far from being a close deal if you analyse the situation right now.\n\n\"Borussia has said that Barcelona have not got any close to their price tag for Dembele, \u20ac150m (\u00a3136m), and there is no price for Coutinho. That's where the situation is at the moment.\n\n\"Liverpool insist they will not sell and they have no intention of meeting Barca right now, despite all the false stories about meetings between clubs coming from the Catalan press, which the club have no influence about.\n\nCoutinho has been heavily linked with a move to the Nou Camp after handing in a transfer request at Anfield, with reports in the Catalan press suggesting a deal is now just days away, although Liverpool insist the Brazil international is not for sale and have already rejected two offers from Barcelona, the last one of \u00a390.4m.\n\nDortmund have turned down an identical offer for their France international Dembele, who is currently serving an internal suspension at the German club after missing training amid the speculation surrounding his future.\n\nBalague believes Segura's words infer that Barcelona are doing all they can to get the deals done, rather than any confirmation being close.\n\n\"If you ask Barca, they would tell you everyone is playing their part and they think they can get one, if not both, of the players. But that is their impression, which right now is not backed up by any evidence.\n\n\"The confusion is Pep Segura uses the words Coutinho and Dembele, and uses the word 'close', which if you shorten the sentence, there you have a story taken out of context.\n\n\"He was trying to say they are doing what they can to get these two players, not necessarily that they are close to confirming.\"\n\nGuillem's Twitter Q&A is back on Friday lunchtime on SkySports.com... get your questions into him by using the #AskGuillem hashtag.\n\nAlso See: Segura: Coutinho close to Barca deal {"id": "9953950", "categories": [{"id": 597, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/UEFA", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/UEFA", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 673, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/AFC", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/AFC", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 822, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian Rules", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian_Rules", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711597374", "source": {"id": "186", "title": "Sify", "uri": "sify.com"}, "url": "http://www.sify.com/sports/liverpool-reject-fresh-125m-offer-for-philippe-coutinho-news-news-risvM5didjgdh.html", "body": "[UK], August 18 (ANI): Liverpool have rejected a fresh a \u20ac125 million offer from Barcelona for Philippe Coutinho, thus maintaining their \"definitive stance\" that the Brazilian mid-fielder will not be sold this summer and will remain a Liverpool player when the window closes.\n\nYesterday, Barcelona general manager Pep Segura had claimed that the club was \"close\" to signing Coutinho.\n\nLast Friday, Coutinho had submitted a transfer request to Liverpool, hours after the club came out with a statement that they will not be selling the mid-fielder, reports goal.com.\n\nShattering the hopes of Barcelona, a statement on Liverpool's website echoed, \"The club's definitive stance is that no offers for Coutinho will be considered and he will remain a member of Liverpool Football Club when the summer window closes.\"\n\nBarcelona had offered \u00a372 million for the player in its first bid, which was rejected. Liverpool stood firm in its stance and also rejected the second bid of \u00a390.4 million.\n\nCoutinho, was signed by Liverpool for \u00a38.5 million in January 2013 for a five-year deal which did not include buy-out clause.\n\nThe 25-year-old star of Liverpool notched 14 goals for the team in last term. The lead scorer of the team helped the Reds to finish fourth in the Premier league. (ANI)\n\nSEARCH", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T18:18:00Z", "extractedDates": [{"textEnd": 15, "textStart": 6, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-18", "amb": false}, {"textEnd": 1058, "textStart": 1046, "date": "2013-01-", "amb": false}], "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370102", "time": "18:18:00", "lang": "eng", "eventUri": "eng-3370102", "location": null, "concepts": [{"id": "86727", "label": {"eng": "Liverpool"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liverpool", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Liverpool"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United Kingdom"}}}, "score": 5}, {"id": "151106", "label": {"eng": "Barcelona"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barcelona", "type": "loc", "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Barcelona"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Spain"}}}, "score": 5}, {"id": "311810", "type": "wiki", "label": {"eng": "Liverpool F.C."}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liverpool_F.C.", "score": 3}, {"id": "432717", "type": "person", "label": {"eng": "Philippe Coutinho"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philippe_Coutinho", "score": 3}], "image": "http://static.sify.com/cms/commons/widget/images/featured-thumbs-default-img.gif", "timeCrawl": "18:18:00", "isDuplicate": false, "title": "Liverpool reject fresh \u20ac 125M offer for Philippe Coutinho", "originalArticle": null}
{"id": "10114768", "categories": [{"id": 14, "label": "dmoz/Sports", "uri": "dmoz/Sports", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 673, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/AFC", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/AFC", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 822, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian Rules", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian_Rules", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-19", "uri": "712061036", "source": {"id": "1734", "title": "Goal.com", "uri": "goal.com"}, "url": "http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/liverpool-would-be-stupid-to-cash-in-on-philippe-coutinho/ilkfqvtjm5vv16ppq057dv6b7", "body": "The Reds rejected the 25-year-old's transfer request as well as three bids from the Catalan club and even if it gets ugly, they must remain unmoved\n\nCOMMENT\n\nThey are words tattooed to transfer windows past, repeated near daily in the present: 'No-one is bigger than Liverpool FC'.\n\nThe phrase, affixed to Fernando Torres, Luis Suarez and Raheem Sterling in recent history, is trending again on the subject of Philippe Coutinho, who is counter-pressing the Reds' refusal to sell him to Barcelona this summer.\n\nRelated Liverpool reject fresh \u20ac125m offer from Barcelona for Coutinho and maintain he's not for sale Henderson hopes 'world class' Coutinho stays at Liverpool Inside Liverpool's fight to keep Coutinho against hostile Barcelona transfer games Barca taking dirty transfer tactics to the extreme with Coutinho & Dembele\n\nThe sentence is a simple and powerful one, but is often erroneously viewed solely in the context of a player wanting to exit Anfield, with the intimation that the club will carry on if he departs.\n\nThe real potency of the message, though, is that the desire of any individual - footballer or otherwise - should always be secondary to what is in the best interests of Liverpool.\n\nSo what exactly is that right now?\n\nHaving broken into the top four for only the second time in eight years last season, the Merseysiders do not just want to carry on.\n\nThey have the \"highest ambitions\", a point communicated more than once by manager Jurgen Klopp, and they cannot truly advance if they cave to Coutinho's wish and service Barca's needs rather their own.\n\nThe Catalan club have seen three formal proposals - bloated by ridiculous add-ons - rebuffed for the Brazil international, whose transfer request was rejected last Friday as the Reds stick to their \"definitive stance\" that he is not for sale this summer.\n\nIt does not matter how disagreeable the situation becomes as Coutinho acts out of desperation - as was the case with Suarez motioning for a switch to Arsenal four years ago, the long-term result is bound to outweigh the immediate hassle.\n\nLiverpool have prepared for 2017-18 on the proviso that they would be enhancing their foundation, not removing an integral frame from it.\n\n\"The main thing I think about is how we can make the next step with the players we had last season,\" Klopp said on July 18.\n\n\"The good news is we didn't lose - and we will not lose - a player we want to keep this summer.\n\n\"That's the best news actually and then we'll see who can bring into the squad.\"\n\nA receding of the emphatic statement by owners Fenway Sports Group that \"no offers for Philippe will be considered\" and he will still be on their books come September 1 would flip the middle finger to the above and elevate the pressure on an already strenuous recruitment drive.\n\nThere are less than two weeks to go before yellow ties and purple dildos signal deadline day. The opinion that Liverpool should \"cash in\" on the 25-year-old, who has missed the start of the season through a convenient back injury, and seek to replace him suggests those advocating it, including ex-players, must have been sleepwalking through the window thus far.\n\nThe Reds have yet to tick off two priorities identified before the close of last season: an aerially dominant centre-back, confident on the ball and composed in big spaces, plus a dynamo in the centre of the park.\n\nTheir willingness to make Virgil van Dijk the most expensive defender in the world was met with a tapping-up allegation from Southampton in June, leading to the club making a public apology and 'ending all interest' in the 26-year-old.\n\nSaints maintain they will not sanction a sale for the Netherlands international, despite his agitation for an exit, a position yet to be tested by a blockbuster bid. RB Leipzig, meanwhile, turned down two lucrative approaches from Liverpool for midfielder Naby Keita - the second of which equalled the Bundesliga record for a transfer - with the same line the English side have served Barca: no deal no matter the price.\n\nHaving already encountered obstinate clubs, and with the knowledge that in this warped climate money doesn't necessarily get you what you want when you want it, why should the Reds cede their star performer to a team they ultimately want to compete with just to get more of it?\n\nWho can they realistically buy, at this stage of the summer, that is of equal or superior quality to Coutinho?\n\nAnd in a maddening market, for how much?\n\nWith time depreciating, cracking the transfer conundrums they already have is proving taxing enough for Liverpool without chucking 'Replace Best Player' into the equation.\n\nThe club have curated a front three of Sadio Mane, Roberto Firmino and Mohamed Salah to profit from Coutinho's cerebral, defence-dissecting service.\n\nThe idea was to have one the most explosive, varied forward lines in Europe being supplied by one of the game's premier playmakers. You cannot have fireworks if there's nobody to light the fuse and without 'The Magician', especially given Adam Lallana's absence through a thigh injury for a minimum of two months, Liverpool do not have experienced, creative architects in their squad.\n\nThey need to be sourcing more quality in that department, not waving bye bye to their world-class element of it.\n\nThere are, of course, understandable concerns over how the Coutinho saga is affecting the dressing room as well as the backroom staff.\n\nKlopp has been visibly frustrated by the endless questions over the Brazilian's future, and given the German's emphasis on the collective, he'll be vexed that the talk around Liverpool centres around an individual who doesn't even want to be there.\n\nTrust, commitment and respect are all crucial to the 50-year-old, and he will feel betrayed on all three accounts in this situation.\n\nCoutinho's actions will be all the more perplexing to the manager considering the discussions the pair had at the tail end of last year, while the player was nursing ankle ligament damage.\n\nKlopp sketched a high-definition picture to his prized asset of the shifting landscape in European football, where superpowers like Barca - ironically - were starting to weaken and Liverpool, given their trajectory and vision, could restore themselves amongst the continent's elite.\n\nIn the meetings, it was also explained to Coutinho that he would be the on-pitch instigator of this progress, and as they moved forward together, the adulation he'd receive from the Kop would be ceaseless.\n\nThe Rio-born talent was convinced enough to sign a new five-year deal in January without a release clause, and his camp arranged an interview with the Daily Mail shortly afterwards - not in conjunction with Liverpool - in which he said: \"My heart is here. I do not think about any other club. Not at all.\"\n\nHe echoed those thoughts in May, and upon returning to Melwood for pre-season training on July 11, described his happiness at being back at the club and his ambitions for the season with Liverpool.\n\nEverything that has happened since, ignited by Neymar's world-record switch from Camp Nou to Paris Saint-Germain, has turned the market on its head and turned Coutinho's head.\n\nWith Barca unable to get Liverpool to negotiate, the onus has fallen on the Reds' two-time Player of the Season to force them to soften their position as is the case with Ousmane Dembele at Borussia Dortmund.\n\nIf he opts for the extreme route, Coutinho would do well to revisit the Suarez saga of 2013 when the Uruguayan admitted he took steps while \"desperate, confused and feeling stuck\" that he quickly came to regret.\n\nReintegrating the striker wasn't an issue for former manager Brendan Rodgers, despite them not speaking properly for just over two months. There was relief in the dressing room that he was staying and there was no doubt the forward would continue to perform to devastating effect.\n\nIt would be the same for Coutinho, especially with a World Cup next year, and it should be remembered that bar four players in the senior squad - Trent Alexander-Arnold, Jon Flanagan, Ben Woodburn and Ryan Kent - everyone else has moved to Liverpool to further their careers.\n\nThey will understand his ambition and that it has been, as per captain Jordan Henderson's assessment \"a difficult period\" for him.\n\nArticle continues below\n\nSo se queda! Nothing to say from our side,\" Klopp told reporters on Thursday.\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they are saying; I don't even know them -- especially this guy, I've never even met him.\"\n\nQuizzed on whether there had been any recent talks at all, Klopp added: \"I am not sure I have to answer this only because we have said what we have to say, or the club said what we have to say.\n\n\"No news from me because no-one told me anything different since we spoke last time about this.\"\n\nThere have been suggestions Coutinho could agitate for a move by effectively going on strike, but while he is still injured that is impossible.\n\nKlopp conceded it is a tricky situation for all parties, but was keen not to be seen criticising the Brazilian's attitude.\n\n\"To be honest I have nothing to say about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he has obviously not been in training,\" he said.\n\n\"I asked the medical department how he is doing and there are no complaints so that is how it is. optimistic they would be playing at the Nou Camp this season\n\nGet FC Barcelona updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nBarcelona are \"close\" to signing Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele, according to the club's sporting director.\n\nThe Catalan side, who lost 2-0 to Real Madrid in the second leg of the Spanish Super Cup on Wednesday night, are looking to bolster their squad following the departure of Neymar to Paris Saint-Germain.\n\nBarcelona have identified Liverpool midfielder Coutinho and Dortmund forward Dembele as their primary targets and look set to spend all of the \u20ac222million they received from Neymar's sale on new acquisitions.\n\nDortmund are understood to have accepted a bid for Dembele, 20, which could rise to as much as \u20ac130million (\u00a3118million) with add-ons.\n\nLiverpool are determined to hold on to Coutinho, who signed a new five-year contract just last season, but Barcelona feel a bid of around \u00a3120million might be enough.\n\nSpeaking on Wednesday night, Barcelona's sporting director Pep Segura admitted the club was in conversations with both players and added he was optimistic they would be playing at the Nou Camp this season.\n\n\"We are close to Coutinho and Dembele, we are discussing their conditions but we do not know when they will be sealed,\" Segura told Spanish television station TV3. \"We hope they will be Barcelona players this season.\"\n\nBarcelona fans will indeed be hoping they can add to their squad after they were comprehensively outplayed in the Super Cup by rivals Real.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now\n\nMarco Asensio, who also struck a when he capitalised on slack defending to fire home from Marcelo's low cross, while Lucas Vazquez hit the post for Madrid.\n\nLionel Messi's chip hit the bar as Barcelona tried to respond and Suarez
