{"id": "9992047", "categories": [{"id": 597, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/UEFA", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/UEFA", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 673, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/AFC", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Soccer/AFC", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 822, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian Rules", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian_Rules", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711704136", "source": {"id": "1228", "title": "Herald Sun", "uri": "heraldsun.com.au"}, "url": "http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/football/breakdown-of-barcelonas-bid-for-philippe-coutinho-reveals-it-is-closer-to-80-million-pounds/news-story/3fc0eff2106c3c06270a9e39ff1b8ae0", "body": "FC BARCELONA are playing a very desperate game of smokes and mirrors.\n\nWhile trying to muscle their way into taking Philippe Coutinho from Liverpool, hoping player power forces the Premier League club's hand, there's also further evidence that the Catalan club cannot truly afford the inflated offer they're throwing at the Anfield hierarchy.\n\nA third transfer bid was rejected by Liverpool on Friday night, with the figure of \u00a3118m being widely reported for Coutinho, who will not be involved against Crystal Palace this weekend.\n\nHowever, The Times reports the bid included \u00a336.5m in add-ons for a player they suggest \"has told Jurgen Klopp, the Liverpool manager, he does not want to play for the club again\".\n\nReports in The Mirror, and Liverpool Echo, reveal that the guaranteed fee was 'only' in the vicinity of \u00a380m, because the rest of the transfer fee was littered with the following trigger payments: winning multiple trophies in a season, winning multiple Champions League titles, winning the Ballon d'Or and winning multiple trophies and the Ballon d'Or simultaneously. The paper also suggests that the \u00a380m is not being offered as a lump sum, but over five years.\n\nIs that truly enough to convince Liverpool they have to sell? Consider, as a point of comparison, that Southampton defender Virgil van Dijk has been tipped as a \u00a360m target. Why would Liverpool sell their talisman for marginally more than a centre-back with 18 months Premier League experience, for a fee where over \u00a330m of the windfall might never appear?\n\nDespite netting \u00a3200m for Neymar, Barcelona have a monumental wage bill - including upgraded terms waiting for Lionel Messi to agree to - and looming Camp Nou renovation to fund, making up-front transfer payments for Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele extremely tough to pull off.\n\nA solution could come, ironically, via Paris Saint-Germain. Mundo Deportivo in Spain have reported that Julian Draxler, who has been reportedly told by Unai Emery he is surplus to requirements at Parc de Princess, has been shopped around to the La Liga club.\n\nThe flurry of Barca bids is a massive test of Liverpool's resolve, and their desire to stand their ground and defy football's transfer pecking order.\n\nBBC Sport's chief football writer Phil McNulty declared that the club's \"instant dismissal\" of the latest bid is \"further hard evidence of the determination within the club that they will not be forced into selling their prized asset under any circumstances\".\n\nBut The Telegraph add that Barcelona will not relent; Coutinho feels he has been a good servant and wants to cash in on the \"once in a lifetime\" opportunity, while Barcelona will need to consider upping, or re-structuring, their current bid.\n\nIndeed, Spanish football expert Guillem Balague says that despite the bravado of Barcelona's General Manager Josep Segura saying the deal was 'close', that is far from reality and just a front.\n\n\"Reading between the lines, he is trying to say - and I have spoken to all the relevant sources - that Barca want both players and they are in talks with their representatives. Not more than that. Even though if you take a sentence from it out of context it sounds different,\" he said on TV3.\n\n\"It means they still need to do deals with the clubs and that will not be easy, in fact, it is far from being a close deal if you analyse the situation right now.\n\n\"Borussia has said that Barcelona have not got any close to their price tag for Dembele, \u20ac150m (\u00a3136m), and there is no price for Coutinho. That's where the situation is at the moment.\n\n\"Liverpool insist they will not sell and they have no intention of meeting Barca right now, despite all the false stories about meetings between clubs coming from the Catalan press, which the club have no influence about.\"\n\nHe concludes: \"If you ask Barca, they would tell you everyone is playing their part and they think they can get one, if not both, of the players. But that is their impression, which right now is not backed up by any evidence.\n\n\"The confusion is Pep Segura uses the words Coutinho and Dembele, and uses the word 'close', which if you shorten the sentence, there you have a story taken out of context.\n\n\"He was trying to say they are doing what they can to get these two players, not necessarily that they are close to confirming.\"\n\nThere's two weeks for Liverpool to hold out, and former Premier League midfielder Jermaine Jenas told BBC Radio 5 live's Firday Football Social doing so would be \"cutting off your nose to spite your own face\".\n\n\"Coutinho has done brilliantly for Liverpool. Yes, they have helped develop him, but the fact is that now the deal of a lifetime has presented itself - not just for him but for the club.\n\n\"Once the owners started to get involved, though, it became about power. It's one thing it coming from the manger's mouth - there being a feeling that he shouldn't be sold - but now they are in a situation that sets a precedent for future deals.\"\n\nHe said that Coutinho would feel aggrieved having witnessed the Reds yielding to Raheem Sterling and Luis Suarez in recent years.\n\n\"If a player deserves to move on to bigger things, like Barcelona, it should almost be like: 'Thank you for everything, you've done brilliantly, now on your way.'\"\n\nClub legend Phil Thompson told Sky Sports that the club needed to still be preparing contingencies in the background - however, three of his nominations, Sergio Aguero, Dele Alli and a hard bargain with Barca for Luis Suarez, are seemingly fanciful.\n\nThompson told Sky Sports: \"Signing Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain would be a start and would be available for the right money with his contract situation at Arsenal, but the club need to be ready to move if they do sell so we're not caught short.\"\n\nThe fallout from Barcelona's situation is being felt across Europe.\n\nIn Germany, Dembele's teammates continue to round on his walkout last week, but teammate Gonzalo Castro added people \"shouldn't forget that he's only 20\".\n\nCastro told Bild: \"He was always there, he played an outstanding season. And all of a sudden, he doesn't show up for training.\n\n\"We were shocked -- it was new to us. I've never experienced anything like this.\n\n\"You can be sure that [if Dembele were to return] we'd tell him quite clearly that you can't act like that and that his behaviour is damaging the team.\"\n\nHe added: \"What I know from my own experience is that I was not able to make every decision on my own when I was 20. But it's also clear that there are contracts and the club stands above everything.\"\n\nFormer Dortmund star Matthias Sammer told Die Welt: \"The club's big strengths -- the family spirit, the togetherness, the club's aura -- are in danger.\n\n\"Those things which make Dortmund strong are damaged. It's incredibly different for the hierarchy.\n\n\"I can't understand anyone who has any sympathy for a player who does not show up for training. That's a no-go.\"", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T23:51:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "details": {}, "storyUri": "eng-3370102", "time": "23:51:00", "Barcelona are hot on the Brazilian's heels - here's what fans think about one of the biggest sagas of the summer\n\nGet Liverpool FC updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email\n\nPhilippe Coutinho 's future at Liverpool is in doubt amid interest from Barcelona.\n\nThe Reds are desperate to hang on to the wantaway Brazilian, who still has a long-term contract at Anfield, reports the Liverpool Echo.\n\nHowever, Barcelona have stepped up their pursuit after the departure of Neymar and are confident of sealing the deal.\n\nCoutinho has yet to feature for Jurgen Klopp's men so far this season due to a back complaint.\n\nAnd the midfielder has reportedly told his boss that he has played his final game in a Red shirt.\n\nHere's what the fans think about one of the biggest transfer sagas of the summer:\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now 'Nice guy' Coutinho to show his true colours\n\nLast January we saw the pictures of a beaming Philippe Coutinho after signing a new five-year deal worth a reputed \u00a3150,000 a week with the Reds, taking him up to the summer of 2022.\n\nHe was quoted as saying he was \"delighted\" to sign a new contract, \"he loves the fans, the club and the City of Liverpool\" and \"Jurgen Klopp is a winner\" and he was looking forward to the future with LFC.\n\nFast forward just eight months later to today, and we see a moody Coutinho, wanting to leave LFC after putting in a transfer request.\n\nThere are rumours coming from his camp that he does not see eye to eye with the manager and that LFC always make it difficult for players to leave.\n\nCoutinho states he has a \"back injury\" but how often in the past have we witnessed these prima donna footballers, who really do live in a different world than the man in the street, feign injury or state they are not in the \"right frame of mind\" to play, in order to gain the mega bucks move that they crave.\n\nNow I am not saying for definite here that Coutinho is feigning injury, but it does seem a strange coincidence that he has a \"bad back\" at this time when he and his agent are chasing a move to Barcelona.\n\nA player all LFC fans thought loved the club and was a \"nice guy\" has shown his true colours and true character - and it ain't a pretty sight.\n\nIf the club go ahead and sell Coutinho against the wishes of Klopp it would surely break the trust between the boardroom & the manager and surely when that happens there is only one outcome.\n\nI expect Liverpool Football to adhere to the wishes of Jurgen Klopp and refuse point blank to bow to Barcelona, Coutinho and his agent's demands.\n\nWouldn't be it be nice, if for the first time a club of the stature of Liverpool FC says \"enough is enough\" and demand that the player fulfills his five year contract he willingly signed just a few months ago.\n\nModern football in 2017 - it stinks.\n\nGraham Agg, Netherton\n\nRead More Football transfer news 2017 Reds would need to recruit two inferior replacements\n\nThe argument from some pundits to sell Phillippe Coutinho and invest in other areas of the side is nonsensical.\n\nThe Brazilian's skill-set of vision and weight of pass to dissect a low block defence is irreplaceable and instantly changes the side's realistic ambitions for the season.\n\nAdd to the fact Coutinho is two players in one, being a number eight and higher left sided forward means Liverpool would have to replace two positions with players of inferior quality.\n\nThe club have been willing to spend upwards of \u00a3140million on the two targets identified as elite level purchases with sellers refusing to do business.\n\nWhy would this change with two weeks of the window to go, alongside the issue of replacing Coutinho's world class talent.\n\nSimply put it wouldn't and Liverpool would be an inferior side.\n\nMark Baker, Huyton\n\nAim big - throw all the Coutinho money on Deli Alli\n\n'A bad back' seems to be the most appropriate phrase for the start of our season. That can't be right?\n\nI don't think its simply a matter of personnel either. Even if we manage to get Virgil Van Dijk, our defensive coaching still needs vast improvement.\n\nThe Coutinho saga needs resolution. I hope LFC are currently getting all their transfer target ducks in a row, ready to spend the Barcelona money as soon as the deal is done.\n\nPie in the sky I know, but Spurs don't pay top wages. Their chairman is very financially astute. Deli Alli grew up a Livepool fan.\n\nSay we offered them all the Barca money for Alli, and offered him double his salary, would they both just say no? Remember, we had the money to buy Van Dijk AND Keita even before Barcelona came calling so it wouldn't eliminate our other plans.\n\nCome on Liverpool. AIM BIG!\n\nSimon Donnelly, Freshfield\n\nIt could be the worst transfer window since 2010\n\nTo not improve our defence adequately over the summer is not acceptable in my opinion. It has been well known that a new centre back was required but we have not strengthened enough.\n\nPersonally I think that this transfer window has been one of the most disappointing in recent years.\n\nMo Salah is an excellent signing but aside from that, to get into the Champions League yet still end up in this situation shows incompetence from those in charge.\n\nIan Ayre was always blamed in the past when we couldn't get deals over the line but those in charge now have really underperformed.\n\nThere was genuine excitement amongst the fans at the end of last season but since then not one of the manager's first choice targets - Keita, Van Dyke, Brandt, Oxlade-Chamberlain, Sessegnon - have been secured.\n\nOn top of that we risk losing Philippe Coutinho despite the club knowing that he was always likely to leave and that he has courted Barcelona over the past year.\n\nIt is not quite as bad the Roy Hodgson window of the summer of 2010 when we unveiled Paul Konchesky and Christian Poulsen - but it is not far off.\n\nMichael Atherton, Crosby\n\npoll loading Should Liverpool sell or keep Philippe Coutinho this summer? 21000+ VOTES SO FAR SELL KEEP", "dateTime": {"id": "9874606", "categories": [{"id": 99, "label": "dmoz/Business/Business Services/Signage", "uri": "dmoz/Business/Business_Services/Signage", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711392375", "source": {"id": "16", "title": "The Sun", "uri": "thesun.co.uk"}, "url": "https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/4269827/barcelona-philippe-countinho-liverpool/", "body": "After rejecting two bids from the Catalan giants, the Reds are adamant that the Brazilian will be staying at Anfield this season\n\nBARCELONA'S sporting director Robert Fernandez has admitted that the La Liga side are facing an uphill battle to sign Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho this summer.\n\nThe Brazilian midfielder does not have a release clause, which is making the transfer difficult to seal for the Spanish giants.\n\nCoutinho handed in a transfer request last week, but Reds boss Jurgen Klopp remains adamant that the Brazilian is staying at Anfield.\n\nLiverpool have already turned down two bids of \u00a372million and \u00a390million from the La Liga outfit for their midfield ace.\n\nHowever, Barcelona are reportedly set to test Liverpool's resolve by launching a huge \u00a3118million offer for Coutinho.\n\n\"Not just Barca, but any team looking for top quality players are getting involved in a very difficult situation in this market,\" Fernandez said.\n\n\"Why? Because the market is where clubs like us want to sign top quality players. There's no buy-out clause so that makes things trickier.\n\n\"Yes, we are negotiating with clubs to make several signings, but in all awareness of the difficulty. We need to work our way into a favourable situation and hopefully close these deals as quickly as possible.\"\n\nBarcelona completed the signing of Paulinho earlier this week, but the Catalans are keen to also sign Borussia Dortmund's Ousmane Dembele.\n\n\"With respect to Liverpool and Dortmund, when there are negotiations you need time, you need to work things into a favourable situation for players and ourselves,\" Fernandez added.\n\n\"We still have days ahead of us, would like to move things faster, but do admit they're two players we would like here. Jose Mourinho\n\nBarcelona had a third bid worth \u00a3118million turned down for Coutinho on Friday.\n\nLiverpool have insisted their playmaker is not for sale at any price, but Coutinho has handed in a transfer request and is attempting to force his way out of the club.\n\nThe third bid may have been worth a record fee for a Premier League player, but the money was not guaranteed.\n\nLiverpool 2017/18 Fixtures\n\nCrystal Palace (H) - Sat Aug 19\n\n1899 Hoffenheim (H) - Wed Aug 23\n\nArsenal (H) - Sun Aug 27\n\nMan City (A) - Sat Sep 9\n\nBurnley (H) - Sat Sep 16\n\nLeicester City (A) - Sat 23 Sep\n\nNewcastle (A) - Sun 1 Oct\n\nBarcelona's offer is made up of potential add-ons, for example if Coutinho wins multiple Champions League medals or a Ballon d'Or, Liverpool would be entitled to a bonus.\n\nIt is believed the money upfront would be around \u00a382m and Catalan outlet Mundo Deportivo claim Liverpool have told Barcelona the add-ons are not acceptable.\n\nLiverpool want most of the \u00a3118m fee immediately as they want to reinvest the funds into new players this summer.\n\nBarcelona will continue to pursue Coutinho until the window slams shut and will accelerate their efforts to sign him even further this week.\n\nThe Spanish giants have timed their past bids on the eve of important games for Liverpool.\n\nCoutinho's transfer request on the eve of the new season followed a second bid while the third offer comes the day before Liverpool's first home game of the campaign.\n\nLiverpool's statement on Coutinho 'The club's definitive stance is that no offers for Philippe will be considered and he will remain a member of Liverpool Football Club when the summer window closes.'\n\nJurgen Klopp has ordered FSG to keep hold of Coutinho, but has refused to rule out any further transfer business.\n\n'A transfer window is a very important time but it's also important what we do with the actual team,' he said.\n\n'We will see what happens. I don't know actually.\n\n'A few things could happen on both sides. Obviously, everything leads in the direction of August 31.\n\n'I can imagine it will be a busy day. If we are involved in that busy day I don't know. We will see.'\n\nCoutinho is currently unavailable for selection with the midfielder citing a back problem.\n\nMORE: Paris Saint-Germain will not sell Liverpool and Arsenal transfer target Julian Email\n\nBarcelona are facing an uphill battle to sign Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho because he does not have a release clause, the club's sporting director Robert Fernandez has admitted.\n\nJurgen Klopp is braced for a third bid for the 25-year-old after the Reds have previously rejected \u00a372million and \u00a390million offers from the Catalans, report the Liverpool Echo .\n\nLiverpool are digging their heels in over the Brazilian though and remain adamant they will not sell him this summer, despite the fact he submitted a transfer request last week.\n\nThis comes after Barca general manager Pep Segura was quoted as saying the La Liga side were \"close\" to securing a deal, but Fernandez was less optimistic as he spoke about a \"very difficult situation\".\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now\n\nBarca, who completed the signing of Paulinho on Thursday, want to spend their \u00a3200million windfall from the sale of Neymar on deals for Coutinho and Borussia Dortmund's Ousmane Dembele.\n\n\"Not just Barca but any team looking for top quality players are getting involved in a very difficult situation in this market,\" Fernandez said.\n\n\"Why? Because the market is where clubs like us want to sign top quality players. There's no buy-out clauses so that makes things trickier.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now\n\n\"Yes, we are negotiating with clubs to make several signings, but in all awareness of the difficulty. We need to work our way into a favourable situation and hopefully close these deals as quickly as possible.\n\n\"Dembele and Coutinho are two important players that we like a lot and have done for a long time. They have the conditions, the right age and could adapt to our football. They would be good to have here. That's the reality.\n\n\"With respect to Liverpool and Dortmund, when there are negotiations you need time, you need to work things into a favourable situation for players and ourselves.\n\n\"We still have days ahead of us, would like to move things faster, but do admit they're two players we would like here. Amit Shah resigns as MLA, says Congress will be reduced to half in next pollsPriyanka Chopra trolled for disrespecting Indian flagDisney CEO sees a future without Netflix, Comcast or DirecTV\n\nLiverpool midfielder Philippe Coutinho, who is a target for Barcelona, has not recovered from a back injury and will miss Saturday's Premier League match against Crystal Palace, manager Juergen Klopp said.\n\nCoutinho, who submitted a transfer request last week according to British media reports, missed Liverpool's 3-3 draw at Watford last Saturday and the first leg of their Champions League playoff, a 2-1 win over Hoffenheim on Tuesday.\n\n\"Phil is not available. Not in training so far,\" Klopp told reporters on Thursday, adding that he had nothing negative to say about the player's attitude.\n\nBarcelona's sporting manager Pep Segura said on Wednesday that the Spanish club were \"close\" to signing Coutinho, despite Liverpool's manager and owners saying the 25-year-old is not for sale. Klopp said on Thursday that nothing had changed with their stance.\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they're saying (about Coutinho moving to Barcelona). I don't even know him (Segura). I have never met him,\" Klopp said.\n\n\"We are not silly, we know it is a very difficult situation - but there's nothing new to say. It's not always easy for me to say the 100 percent truth... But this time this is the situation.\"\n\nLiverpool have had a relatively quiet transfer window compared to many of their rivals, signing defender Andrew Robertson, winger Mohamed Salah and striker Dominic Solanke.\n\nThey have been linked in British media with moves for Southampton defender Virgil van Dijk and midfielder Naby Keita from RB Leipzig, but both players' clubs have said they are not for sale at any price.\n\nFans have expressed frustration with Liverpool's failure to invest further in a squad that finished fourth in the Premier League last season, but Klopp said that he was happy with the players he has already.\n\n\"The whole market is difficult,\" Klopp said. \"If the transfer window had ended yesterday we already have a team I like. The transfer window is a very important time, but it's also important what we do with the actual team.\"\n\nThe manager said striker Daniel Sturridge, who sustained a thigh injury in pre-season, is fit to return for Liverpool's first home game of the season, which could prove a tough encounter.\n\nPalace, who lost their opening match 3-0 at home to promoted Huddersfield, could become the first side to win four straight Premier League matches at Anfield.\n\n\"I am really looking forward to Anfield. It's our place. It's been a long time since we played there,\" Klopp said. \"We know it is a tough game. {"id": "9624085", "categories": [], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710713494", "source": {"id": "2530", "title": "Firstpost", "uri": "firstpost.com"}, "url": "http://www.firstpost.com/sports/barcelona-close-to-signing-philippe-coutinho-and-ousmane-dembele-says-general-manager-pep-segura-3939827.html", "body": "Madrid: Barcelona could be handed a lift after losing 5-1 on aggregate to Real Madrid in the Spanish Super Cup as a senior official claimed the club are \"close\" to signing Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele.\n\nPep Segura, Barcelona's general manager, said negotiations with Liverpool for Brazilian playmaker Coutinho and Borussia Dortmund over a deal for promising French winger Dembele could be finalised within days.\n\nLiverpools's Philippe Coutinho and Borussia Dortmund's Ousmane Dembele. AP\n\n\"We have to help the team with reinforcements and they will be here in the coming days,\" Segura told Catalan TV station Esport3 after Barca lost the second leg of the Super Cup 2-0 at Madrid's Santiago Bernabeu.\n\n\"We are discussing the conditions of Coutinho and Dembele, they are close.\"\n\n\"We hope they will be Barca players next season.\"\n\nBarca's season has been thrown into turmoil by Neymar's world record \u20ac 222 million ($261 million) move to Paris Saint-Germain earlier this month.\n\nNew Barcelona coach Ernesto Valverde admitted Neymar's absence has affected the balance of the side.\n\nMeanwhile, the Catalans have struggled to close deals for Coutinho and Dembele with Liverpool and Dortmund holding out for fees in excess of \u20ac 100 million in the knowledge of Barca's desperation to land a replacement before the transfer window shuts on 31 August.\n\nBarcelona defender Gerard Pique denied reports there is a growing feud between club's players and under-pressure board.\n\nHowever, Pique admitted Barca have plenty of work to do if they are to close they gap on Madrid, who have added to their crowns as European and Spanish champions by winning both the UEFA and Spanish Super Cups in style over the past week.\n\n\"We are not in the best moment. Not as a team or as a club,\" said Pique.\n\n\"We have to stick together and move forward.\"\n\n\"The season is long and it has just begun. Madrid were superior so we have to live with defeat, congratulate them and improve.\"\n\nNo Ronaldo, no problem\n\nDespite missing the suspended Cristiano Ronaldo, whose five-game ban for pushing a referee after being sent off in the first leg was upheld on appeal before kick-off, Madrid were dominant in the first-half.\n\nMarco Asensio's brilliant strike after just four minutes built on Madrid's 3-1 first leg lead and Karim Benzema doubled the hosts' lead on the night just before half-time.\n\nVictory also sealed Madrid's seventh trophy of a spectacularly successful spell since Zinedine Zidane took charge just 20 months ago.\n\n\"We are delighted with how we played in both games, it is another trophy and you have to congratulate the players because they have been fantastic,\" said Zidane.\n\nOn top of the absent Ronaldo, the Frenchman also had the luxury of leaving Gareth Bale and Isco on the bench as the gulf between Madrid and Barca's strength in depth was again laid bare.\n\n\"I have a spectacular squad,\" added Zidane.\n\n\"When you see how Isco played in Barcelona and then I take him out it is a bit harsh, but the players understand how long the season will be and we will need everyone.\"\n\nPublished Date: Aug 17, 2017 11:44 am | Updated Date: Aug 17, 2017 11:44 am\n\nTags :#Barcelona#Borussia dortmund#Cristiano ronaldo#Ernesto Not in training so far,\" Klopp told reporters on Thursday, adding that he had nothing negative to say about the player's attitude.\n\nBarcelona's sporting manager Pep Segura said on Wednesday that the Spanish club were \"close\" to signing Coutinho, despite Liverpool's manager and owners saying the 25-year-old is not for sale.\n\nKlopp said on Thursday that nothing had changed with their stance.\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they're saying (about Coutinho moving to Barcelona). I don't even know him (Segura). I have never met him,\" Klopp said.\n\n\"We are not silly, we know it is a very difficult situation - but there's nothing new to say. It's not always easy for me to say the 100 percent truth... But this time this is the situation.\"\n\nLiverpool have had a relatively quiet transfer window compared to many of their rivals, signing defender Andrew Robertson, winger Mohamed Salah and striker Dominic Solanke.\n\nThey have been linked in British media with moves for Southampton defender Virgil van Dijk and midfielder Naby Keita from RB Leipzig, but both players' clubs have said they are not for sale at any price.\n\nFans have expressed frustration with Liverpool's failure to invest further in a squad that finished fourth in the Premier League last season, but Klopp said that he was happy with the players he has already.\n\n\"The whole market is difficult,\" Klopp said.\n\n\"If the transfer window had ended yesterday we already have a team I like. The transfer window is a very important time, but it's also important what we do with the actual team.\"\n\nThe manager said striker Daniel Sturridge, who sustained a thigh injury in pre-season, is fit to return for Liverpool's first home game of the season, which could prove a tough encounter.\n\nPalace, who lost their opening match 3-0 at home to promoted Huddersfield, could become the first side to win four straight Premier League matches at Anfield.\n\n\"I am really looking forward to Anfield. It's our place. It's been a long time since we played there,\" Klopp said.\n\n\"We know it is a tough game. {"id": "9971499", "categories": [{"id": 822, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian Rules", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian_Rules", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711645393", "source": {"id": "264", "title": "BBC News", "uri": "bbc.co.uk"}, "url": "http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40981512", "body": "Liverpool are damaging themselves by refusing to let midfielder Philippe Coutinho leave for Barcelona, says ex-England international Jermaine Jenas.\n\nThe Reds have rejected three bids - the latest worth about \u00a3114m - from the Spanish giants for Coutinho, who last week submitted a transfer request after the club's owners released a statement insisting he would not be sold.\n\nSpeaking on BBC Radio 5 live's Friday Football Social, Jenas said Liverpool's stance was like \"cutting off your nose to spite your own face\".\n\nHe added: \"Coutinho has done brilliantly for Liverpool. Yes, they have helped develop him, but the fact is that now the deal of a lifetime has presented itself - not just for him but for the club.\n\n\"Once the owners started to get involved, though, it became about power. It's one thing it coming from the manger's mouth - there being a feeling that he shouldn't be sold - but now they are in a situation that sets a precedent for future deals.\"\n\nBarcelona have moved for 25-year-old Coutinho - who signed from Inter Milan for \u00a38.5m in 2013 - after selling Brazil team-mate Neymar to Paris St-Germain for a world record transfer fee of \u00a3200m.\n\nLiverpool, meanwhile, have made two acquisitions this summer. Egypt and former Chelsea winger Mohamed Salah arrived from Roma for \u00a334m in June, before the club paid Hull City \u00a310m for Scotland left-back Andrew Robertson last month.\n\n\"The timing is a problem,\" added ex-Tottenham and Newcastle midfielder Jenas, 34.\n\n\"Barca have got themselves into this situation by selling Neymar when they did, and Liverpool have struggled to make the signings they wanted.\n\n\"If Coutinho goes now, they know they will be in an even harder position - because they failed with bids for Southampton defender Virgil van Dijk and RB Leipzig midfielder Naby Keita and there didn't seem to be a 'Plan B'.\n\n\"But what's also weird about this situation, and another reason why Coutinho probably feels hard done by, is that Liverpool have sold star players in the past - like with Luis Suarez and Raheem Sterling.\n\n\"We had something similar with Dimitar Berbatov when he left Spurs for Manchester United in 2008.\n\n\"If a player deserves to move on to bigger things, like Barcelona, it should almost be like: 'Thank you for everything, you've done brilliantly, now on your way.'\"\n\nBBC Sport chief football writer Phil McNulty\n\nLiverpool's instant dismissal of Barcelona's third offer is further hard evidence of the determination within the club that they will not be forced into selling their prize asset under any circumstances.\n\nFenway Sports Group, and manager Klopp, remain unmoved by Barcelona's increased financial inducements - as well as a transfer request from a player who has clearly had his head turned.\n\nLiverpool regard this latest bid, understood to be about \u00a3114m, as irrelevant because their stance, as it has been from day one, is that Coutinho will not be sold.\n\nBut questions remain. Will Barcelona take the hint and walk away? Will Coutinho, sidelined by a back injury, accept his dream move will not come to fruition and eventually return to the fold? Will his unhappiness increase at the prospect of a switch to the Nou Camp slipping away?\n\nFor all the noises coming out of Barcelona that a move is \"close\", it remains as far away as the day they made their first approach. {"id": "9942140", "categories": [{"id": 822, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian Rules", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/Australian_Rules", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711564741", "source": {"id": "218", "title": "Metro.co.uk", "uri": "metro.co.uk"}, "url": "http://metro.co.uk/2017/08/18/liverpool-legend-phil-thompson-names-three-outrageous-transfer-targets-if-philippe-coutinho-joins-barcelona-6863010/", "body": "Liverpool legend Phil Thompson names three outrageous transfer targets if Philippe Coutinho joins Barcelona Metro Sport Reporter for Metro.co.ukFriday 18 Aug 2017 5:52 pm Share this article with Facebook Share this article with Twitter Share this article with Google Plus Share this article with Whatsapp Share this article through email Share this article through sms\n\nLiverpool legend Phil Thompson has set his sights very high for potential replacements if Philippe Coutinho leaves Anfield this summer.\n\nBarcelona have had a third bid for the Brazilian, understood to be in the region of \u00a3114million, rejected by the Reds.\n\nLiverpool reject staggering bid from Barcelona for Philippe Coutinho\n\nThe Premier League club are insistent that their talisman will not be leaving this summer.\n\nBut if Coutinho, who has handed in a transfer request, were to go then Liverpool would have to find a replacement.\n\nLiverpool statement on Coutinho\n\nThe club's definitive stance is that no offers for Philippe will be considered and he will remain a member of Liverpool Football Club when the summer window closes.\n\nThat would be no easy task, but Thompson has identified some potential options - all of which would go a long way to appeasing Liverpool fans if they could be signed.\n\n'The ideal resolution is that the club will leave it very late and get as much as they can for him,' Thompson told Sky Sports of the Coutinho situation. 'If he doesn't want to stay then I'd rather see him sold for the best price, but the big issue is that there won't be any players near is quality on the market.'\n\nHe continued: 'What they can do is try to find somebody out there, maybe even play Barcelona at their own game and say you can have Coutinho but we want Luis Suarez.\n\n'Suarez might be unhappy with the Neymar situation. You don't know whether a player is unhappy or a club are willing to sell until you ask the question.\n\nThompson continued: 'They could go after Dele Alli, who was a Liverpool supporter as a kid. Tottenham are a bit like Liverpool in that there's always a price on a player.\n\n'Sergio Aguero is another player that might be interested if he's not happy at Manchester City, but it comes back to being late in the window and that is the difficult situation Liverpool find themselves in.'\n\nIn addition to those unlikely targets, Thompson also picked out Arsenal star Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, who has just 12 months remaining on his contract. The England international has been linked with a move to Anfield for some time.\n\n'Signing Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain would be a start and would be available for the right money with his contract situation at Arsenal, but the club need to be ready to move if they do sell so we're not caught short.'\n\nMORE: Barcelona bid of \u00a3114m for Philippe Coutinho rejected by Liverpool\n\nMORE: they continue to find Neymar's replacement.\n\nLiverpool instantly rejected the offer and have kept up their stance that the player is not for sale at any costs.\n\nAnd according to the Times, a frustrated Coutinho has told the German manager that he won't pull on the Liverpool shirt ever again.\n\nThe 25-year-old submitted a transfer request last Friday after Barca stepped up their chase to false, "title": "Philippe Coutinho tells Klopp he 'does not want to play for Liverpool again'", "originalArticle": null}
{"id": "9783080", "categories": [], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "711131013", "source": {"id": "1228", "title": "Herald Sun", "uri": "heraldsun.com.au"}, "url": "http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/football/liverpool-transfer-news-philippe-coutinho-to-barcelona-naby-keita-virgil-van-dijk-christian-pulisic/news-story/b5fcc359a115535eef996e4c2ae4e550", "body": "Philippe Coutinho has handed in his transfer request, a 'back niggle' lingers and Barcelona's media machine continues to pump out talk to unsettle the Reds' star man further.\n\nThe latest talk out of Spain suggests Coutinho has delivered an angry threat never to play for Liverpool again, meaning he's willing to sit out an entire season in a World Cup year in a bid to force Liverpool's hand.\n\nIt could prove to be an ugly end to an inexplicably poor transfer window for Jurgen Klopp's side, which all came unravelling after what seemed to be a positive start.\n\nMohamed Salah had signed on a club record fee, Virgil van Dijk had 'chosen' to come to Merseyside and Naby Keita was seen as a big statement signing to show Liverpool had the financial muscle to compete with the big Premier League spenders.\n\nInstead, Southampton dug their heels in over Van Dijk and RB Leipzig flat out refused to consider selling Keita despite a release clause kicking in next summer transfer window.\n\nIt's left Liverpool in a situation where they're too late to go looking for a Coutinho replacement, where there's money in the bank going unspent and where the pressure from all sides is bubbling over.\n\nHere are the Burning Issues involved in Liverpool's Coutinho saga...\n\nPLAYER POWER CONUNDRUM, BARCA'S DIRTY TRICK\n\nLiverpool made a masterstroke by re-signing Coutinho to a new, long-term deal. In January, Catalan press ran with the headline 'Operation Coutinho' with Barca deciding the 25-year-old would be the prime off-season target.\n\nIt was said Neymar had singled out Coutinho to be the long term replacement for Andres Iniesta. The pressure was beginning to mount on Liverpool and they responded by tying their man down on a five-year deal, crucially without a release clause.\n\nNow, panicked by losing Neymar, Barcelona have finally come calling and are using their allure to back the player into a corner.\n\n\"The problem here is Barcelona,\" explained Liverpool legend Steven Gerrard, a pundit on BT Sport.\n\n\"Because they will be saying to Coutinho's representatives: 'It's now or never. If he doesn't come now, we're never coming back for him ever again.'\n\n\"So they're piling the pressure on and that's why Philippe's reacted.\n\n\"This kid who's come from South America has always had a dream of playing for Barcelona, and he's panicking thinking that if he doesn't do it now it'll never happen again.\"\n\nThis is Barcelona's transfer MO - sound out the player, promise them a dream move and wait for them to become unsettled and force the issue with their club.\n\nDo Liverpool risk holding onto an unhappy player or stand up to Barcelona and Coutinho's play?\n\nWHY LIVERPOOL CAN'T AFFORD TO SELL\n\nFenway Sports Group didn't have to send out the messages they did.\n\nThey didn't have to brief beat writers on the war chest at Klopp's disposal. They didn't have to later state Coutinho would not be sold this summer.\n\nInstead, Liverpool's owners made the club's position clear and public and need to walk the walk to avoid the growing calls of fan unhappiness.\n\nHowever big or small, there is a portion of the Liverpool fan base determined to decry FSG's ownership.\n\nThe promises made, whether real or imagined, this off-season gave the fans hope that Liverpool would keep their stars and strengthen after once again finishing in the top four.\n\nWhen FSG released their brief but firmly worded statement making it clear Coutinho would remain, they nailed that stance in the ground for all to see. It in turn led to the 'Little Magician' instantly submitting a transfer request. To change their tune now would be disastrous for FSG considering they've failed to deliver on spending the money set aside for the Van Dijk and Keita deals.\n\nWILL IT BE TOTALLY DISASTROUS?\n\nPhilippe Coutinho is Liverpool's best player, but that doesn't make him Liverpool's most irreplaceable player.\n\nTo finish last season, the Brazilian dropped into a deeper midfield role in a 4-4-2 diamond and shone. Klopp stated this tweak was a glimpse at what to expect next season. Then he went out and bought Salah.\n\nThat means, alongside Roberto Firmino and Sadio Mane, Liverpool's first choice front three is set. This forces Coutinho into a midfield role, but importantly a midfield role in a 4-3-3.\n\nWith skipper Jordan Henderson a lock as the deepest midfielder when fit, that leaves just one position to fit one of Adam Lallana, Emre Can and Georgino Wijnaldum. If James Milner truly is back to being a midfielder and not a left back, there's another starting contender who could miss out.\n\nThe worry for Klopp is that in past years, Henderson, Lallana and Coutinho have missed substantial chunks of the season with injuries. Sell Coutinho and lose a few key men to knocks and the squad looks worryingly thin to be able to compete, potentially, on multiple fronts.\n\nHowever, if Coutinho stays -- willingly or not -- it presents Klopp with a delicate balancing act to pick a midfield that provides balance to the XI, and does not leave the side as open defensively, as they have the potential to be.\n\nWHO REPLACES COUTINHO?\n\nThe desire to bring in Keita looked and sounded great.\n\nA young, supremely talented midfielder, Keita can be both an energetic box-to-box midfielder and, importantly, a creative playmaker.\n\nHe was proposed, by some on Merseyside, as Coutinho's replacement 12 months in advance. Keita also has buyout clause of \u00a348m that kicks in next year. Liverpool thought, by offering well over that mark, RB Leipzig would want to cash in.\n\nInstead, they've been rebuffed at every turn and to lose Coutinho AND Coutinho's replacement would highlight Liverpool's failings this window.\n\nAnother name mooted has been Christian Pulisic, who reportedly has his heart set on moving to Real Madrid or Barcelona and not to Liverpool. Pulisic is also not the finished product, risking Liverpool continue to stand still when their rivals are growing.\n\nOriginally published as Barca's dirty trick, Reds puzzle teeters on brink", Not in training so far,\" Klopp told reporters on Thursday, adding that he had nothing negative to say about the player's attitude.\n\nBarcelona's sporting manager Pep Segura said on Wednesday that the Spanish club were \"close\" to signing Coutinho, despite Liverpool's manager and owners saying the 25-year-old is not for sale.\n\nKlopp said on Thursday that nothing had changed with their stance.\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they're saying [about Coutinho moving to Barcelona]. I don't even know him [Segura]. I have never met him,\" Klopp said.\n\n\"We are not silly, we know it is a very difficult situation - but there's nothing new to say. It's not always easy for me to say the 100 per cent truth . . . But this time this is the situation.\"\n\nLiverpool have had a relatively quiet transfer window compared to many of their rivals, signing defender Andrew Robertson, winger Mohamed Salah and striker Dominic Solanke.\n\nThey have been linked with moves for Southampton defender Virgil van Dijk and midfielder Naby Keita from RB Leipzig, but both their clubs have said they are not for sale at any price.\n\nFans have expressed frustration with Liverpool's failure to invest further in a squad that finished fourth in the Premier League last season, but Klopp said that he was happy with the players he has already.\n\n\"The whole market is difficult,\" Klopp said. \"If the transfer window had ended yesterday we already have a team I like. The transfer window is a very important time, but it's also important what we do with the actual team.\"\n\nThe manager said striker Daniel Sturridge, who sustained a thigh injury in pre-season, is fit to return for Liverpool's first home game of the season, which could prove a tough encounter.\n\nPalace, who lost their opening match 3-0 at home to promoted Huddersfield, could become the first side to win four straight Premier League matches at Anfield.\n\n\"I am really looking forward to Anfield. It's our place. It's been a long time since we played there,\" Klopp said.\n\n\"We know it is a tough game. Both players are keen to make the move to the Nou Camp.\n\nHowever, the Catalan side are hamstrung by the fact that neither player has a release clause in their respective contracts. It's a much different situation to the one that Barca found themselves in with Neymar where PSG paid a price that was pre-determined is his contract with Barcelona.\n\n\"Coutinho and Dembele are two players that we like very much for their condition and their age and we are negotiating with their respective clubs,\" said Fernandez. \"But we need time to be able to reach a favourable solution.\n\n\"We would like to go a little further and recognise that they want to come, but it's the clubs that will decide if we can make the signings.\"\n\nFernandez added: \"It is not only Bar\u00e7a that has trouble making such signings. It costs all those who want quality players. It is not easy for anyone. They are very good players but they have no release clause.\n\n\"We have negotiated with several clubs to make new signings. There are ways of approaching and dialogue and we hope to close them as soon as possible. \"\n\nBoth Liverpool and Dortmund are continuing to dig in their heels over Coutinho and Dembele. he is not training so far, so there is nothing new,\" manager Jurgen Klopp told reporters at his pre-match press conference on Thursday. \"It is always how it is with injured players, there is no real time on when he is back.\"\n\nQuizzed regarding those comments from Segura, Klopp insisted there was \"nothing new\" on Coutinho to Barcelona and said that he had no complaints about the player's attitude following suggestions that he could be ready to go on strike in order to force a move to the Nou Camp. Liverpool are said to remain unwavering in their stance that he is not for sale at any price.\n\n\"I can't say anything about his attitude because since he has had a back problem he hasn't been in training,\" Klopp added. \"But when I asked the medical department about him they said nothing bad. We are all not silly. It's a difficult situation but there's nothing new to say. I don't like to lie and it's exactly how I say it. Nothing else.\"\n\nWhile Coutinho will not play against Palace, Klopp believes that Daniel Sturridge is ready to feature. It's just the fee that needs to be finalised,\" Price said in an Express Sports report.\n\n\"The German club are holding out for as much as they can possibly get - and more than \u00a390m would be an incredible result for a player that cost them a tenth of that a year ago - which could scupper Barca's interest in Philippe Coutinho.\n\n\"In any case, even with the sale of Neymar, the Catalans couldn't afford both Dembele and Coutinho. I'd want to know the reason why and if it was a club like Barcelona I'd understand.\n\nBellamy joined Manchester City having been allowed to leave West Ham after two years\n\nBarcelona have looked to Coutinho as a replacement for Neymar since his \u00a3198m move to PSG\n\n'I can understand why Liverpool want to hold onto Coutinho - a lot of clubs are taking a hard-line now. They don't have to sell.\n\n'But Coutinho has to want to leave - of course he does. It's very easy to point the fingers at footballers but, no matter what your job is, if you had the chance to go to the best in the business, getting paid way more than you are, then you're going to want to take that offer up.\n\n'In fact, I'd be concerned if Coutinho didn't want to take up Barcelona's offer.\n\nRegardless of the uncertainty surrounding Coutinho's future, Liverpool are actively chasing targets as they look to secure their place in the Champions League group stages following a 2-1 win over Hoffenheim in their play-off first leg.\n\nEarlier this week, Barcelona general manager Pep Segura said a deal for Coutinho, who Liverpool's owners have said will not be leaving the club in this window, was 'close' but Reds boss Jurgen Klopp believes that is not the case.\n\nBellamy returned to the Reds in 2011 where he played for another season under Kenny Dalglish\n\nJurgen Klopp has missed out on a couple of his summer transfer targets and could lose a star\n\nThe German has remained his charismatic self throughout the transfer saga, but Bellamy believes the 50-year-old's patience will begin to wear thin if a resolution is not found soon, with the season now in full swing.\n\nBellamy added: 'I like watching Liverpool under Jurgen Klopp. I enjoy the way they attack, especially on the counter - they're one of the best at it, the pace they break with is immense.\n\n'My concern is when they're attacking in the final third Liverpool seem very venerable to the counter themselves. That's been their biggest weakness with Klopp at the helm and it still hasn't been addressed yet.\n\n'He has tried to sign players to shore the defence up, but he hasn't been able to get those players over the line.\n\n'Klopp will be more frustrated than anyone, because they're what the club needs. But, to me, it looks like unless he gets the player he wants, which looks unlikely, then he's not going to move in the market.'\n\nKlopp needs to address his side's weakness on the counter-attack according to Bellamy\n\nLiverpool have 13 days to hold onto their star for the first half of the Premier League season\n\nCraig Bellamy was speaking exclusively to Paddy Power News. "17001", "title": "The Scottish Sun", "uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk"}, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/sport/football/1441463/liverpool-reject-third-barcelona-bid-for-philippe-coutinho-worth-118million-but-the-real-transfer-figure-is-nowhere-near-that/", "body": "La Liga side inserted a host of improbable add-on clauses, with Reds almost certainly only receiving \u00a380m across five years\n\nLIVERPOOL rejected a third bid from Barcelona for Philippe Coutinho worth \u00a3118million on Friday.\n\nMany were surprised Jurgen Klopp and Co turned down the astronomical sum - particularly given the player's desire to join the Spanish giants.\n\nCoutinho, 25, handed in a transfer request at Liverpool earlier this month in a desperate plea to join Barca just hours after club chiefs said he was going nowhere.\n\nThe Reds have already rejected bids of \u00a372m and \u00a390m this summer, to boot.\n\nHowever, the real reason Liverpool turned their nose up at the mega-money deal has been revealed... and you can see why.\n\nBarcelona were offering the Premier League outfit just \u00a380m in guaranteed fees - and even that was spread out over FIVE years.\n\nOn top of that, Barca had inserted a host of improbable clauses in a bid to make their offer seem more generous.\n\nIn fact, many of those extra millions would almost certainly never see the inside of Liverpool's bank account.\n\nFor starters, the Reds would see a clause activated should Barcelona win multiple trophies in one season.\n\nWhile that sounds reasonably plausible, Barca don't appear to be the force they once were in the Xavi-Andres Inista era of midfield dominance... and they've just lost Neymar.\n\nLiverpool would also see money if Barcelona won multiple Champions League titles of if Coutinho wins the Ballon d'Or during his career.\n\nA further big-money add-on would There's only one option for you.\n\n\"Say in Coutinho's spot, he handed in a transfer request. He did every single thing he possibly could do. Currently, they are a team in decline, but Klopp is buoyant about his own club's prospects having led the Reds to the brink of qualification to the group stage of the Champions League.\n\nHe said: \"Can you imagine for a minute I am not a little bit interested about the problems or not of Barcelona?\n\n\"I will never talk about something I spoke about with a player. But you can imagine, in general, I think for each player Liverpool is a very good club, a very good team in the moment.\n\n\"We have a good age of the group. We have very young boys, experience - it's a good mix and we are on our way.\n\n\"I think we got rid of the expectations of 20 years ago and created our own expectations for all the people. They expect a lot from us because of what we did last season.\n\n\"I am fine with the situation and I am very positive about the project of Liverpool. I don't see a lot of reasons for each player to leave the club at the moment and that's just in general.\"\n\nCoutinho remains sidelined by a back problem and won't feature against Crystal Palace at Anfield on Saturday.\n\nKlopp admits the 25-year-old has been missed during the opening week of the season. The manager shifted Coutinho into an advanced central midfield role towards the end of last term so he could pull the strings to a greater degree.\n\nWith Coutinho and Adam Lallana (thigh) both ruled out, Klopp's midfield options have been reduced and it's an area where Liverpool have lacked dynamism during the games against Watford and Hoffenheim.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now\n\n\"Having Phil not available was never cool for us but it happened,\" Klopp added.\n\n\"In my first year he had the hamstring (injury). We always need to adapt. That's how it is. Obviously you see it as good as it is until it's s*** because it doesn't work.\n\n\"And the reason why it doesn't work is not too important, it's just to find a solution. That's what we did in the moment.\n\n\"Every team in the world would miss a creative player in whichever position of his quality. That's not too cool but I am already used to it. You cannot find exactly the same solution. That's how football works.\n\n\"If Phil could have had just one genius idea on the pitch that would have helped. Absolutely. That's all. But I can't work in my office, make a a line-up and say: 'Ahhh! And here we miss Phil'. That's not how it works.\n\n\"It's a situation in the moment and we have to take it like this. losing 5-1 on aggregate to Real Madrid in the Spanish Super Cup as a senior official claimed the club are \"close\" to signing Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele.\n\nPep Segura, Barca's general manager, said negotiations with Liverpool for Brazilian playmaker Coutinho and Borussia Dortmund over a deal for promising French winger Dembele could be finalised within days.\n\n\"We have to help the team with reinforcements and they will be here in the coming days,\" Segura told Catalan TV station Esport3 after Barca lost the second leg of the Super Cup 2-0 at Madrid's Santiago Bernabeu.\n\n\"We are discussing the conditions of Coutinho and Dembele...they are close.\n\n\"We hope they will be Barca players next season.\"\n\nBarca's season has been thrown into turmoil by Neymar's world record 222 million euro ($261 million) move to Paris Saint-Germain earlier this month.\n\nNew Barca coach Ernesto Valverde admitted Neymar's absence has affected the balance of the side.\n\nMeanwhile, the Catalans have struggled to close deals for Coutinho and Dembele with Liverpool and Dortmund holding out for fees in excess of 100 million euros in the knowledge of Barca's desperation to land a replacement before the transfer window shuts on August 31.\n\nBarca defender Gerard Pique denied reports there is a growing feud between club's players and under-pressure board.\n\nHowever, Pique admitted Barca have plenty of work to do if they are to close they gap on Madrid, who have added to their crowns as European and Spanish champions by winning both the UEFA and Spanish Super Cups in style over the past week.\n\n\"We are not in the best moment. Not as a team or as a club,\" said Pique.\n\n\"We have to stick together and move forward.\n\n\"The season is long and it has just begun. a referee after being sent off in the first leg was upheld on appeal before kick-off, Madrid were dominant in the first-half.\n\nMarco Asensio's brilliant strike after just four minutes built on Zinedine Zidane took charge just 20 months ago.\n\n\"We are delighted with how we played in both games, it is another trophy and you have to congratulate the players because they have been Luis Suarez look dejected after they lost to Real Madrid in the Spanish Super Cup. -- Reuters picMADRID, Aug 17 -- Barcelona could be handed a lift after losing 5-1 on aggregate to Real Madrid in the Spanish Super Cup as a senior official claimed the club are \"close\" to signing Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele.\n\nPep Segura, Barca's general manager, said negotiations with Liverpool for Brazilian playmaker Coutinho and Borussia Dortmund over a deal for promising French winger Dembele could be finalised within days.\n\n\"We have to help the team with reinforcements and they will be here in the coming days,\" Segura told Catalan TV station Esport3 after Barca lost the second leg of the Super Cup 2-0 at Madrid's Santiago Bernabeu.\n\n\"We are discussing the conditions of Coutinho and Dembele...they are close.\n\n\"We hope they will be Barca players next season.\"\n\nBarca's season has been thrown into turmoil by Neymar's world record \u20ac222 million (RM1.12 billion) move to Paris Saint-Germain earlier this month.\n\nNew Barca coach Ernesto Valverde admitted Neymar's absence has affected the balance of the side.\n\nMeanwhile, the Catalans have struggled to close deals for Coutinho and Dembele with Liverpool and Dortmund holding out for fees in excess of \u20ac100 million in the knowledge of Barca's desperation to land a replacement before the transfer window shuts on August 31.\n\nBarca defender Gerard Pique denied reports there is a growing feud between club's players and under-pressure board.\n\nHowever, Pique admitted Barca have plenty of work to do if they are to close they gap on Madrid, who have added to their crowns as European and Spanish champions by winning both the Uefa and Spanish Super Cups in style over the past week.\n\n\"We are not in the best moment. Not as a team or as a club,\" said Pique.\n\n\"We have to stick together and move forward.\n\n\"The season is long and it has just begun. Madrid were superior so we have to live with defeat, congratulate them and improve.\"\n\nNo Ronaldo, no problem\n\nDespite missing the suspended Cristiano Ronaldo, whose five-game ban for pushing a referee after being sent off in the first leg was upheld on appeal before kick-off, Madrid were dominant in the first-half.\n\nMarco Asensio's brilliant strike after just four minutes built on Madrid's 3-1 first leg lead and Karim Benzema doubled the hosts' lead on the night just before half-time.\n\nVictory also sealed Madrid's seventh trophy of a spectacularly successful spell since Zinedine Zidane took charge just 20 months ago.\n\n\"We are delighted with how we played in both games, it is another trophy and you have to congratulate the players because they have been fantastic,\" said Zidane.\n\nOn top of the absent Ronaldo, the Frenchman also had the luxury of leaving Gareth Bale and Isco on the bench as the gulf between Madrid and Barca's strength in depth was again laid bare.\n\n\"I have a spectacular squad,\" added Zidane.\n\n\"When you see how Isco played in Barcelona and then I take him out it is a bit harsh, but the players understand how long the Coutinho has already expressed his desire to leave his current employers as Barcelona remain keen on securing his services.\n\nThe Brazil international has handed in a transfer request to force a move to the Catalan club. "http://www.nation.co.ke/sports/football/Coutinho-Dembele-close-to-battered-Barca/1102-4060520-84wr22z/index.html", "body": "\"We have to help the team with reinforcements and they will be here in the coming days,\" Segura told Catalan TV station Esport3 after Barca lost the second leg of the Super Cup 2-0 at Madrid's Santiago Bernabeu.\n\nBarcelona could be handed a lift after losing 5-1 on aggregate to Real Madrid in the Spanish Super Cup as a senior official claimed the club are \"close\" to signing Philippe Coutinho and Ousmane Dembele.\n\nPep Segura, Barca's general manager, said negotiations with Liverpool for Brazilian playmaker Coutinho and Borussia Dortmund over a deal for promising French winger Dembele could be finalised within days.\n\n\"We have to help the team with reinforcements and they will be here in the coming days,\" Segura told Catalan TV station Esport3 after Barca lost the second leg of the Super Cup 2-0 at Madrid's Santiago Bernabeu.\n\n\"We are discussing the conditions of Coutinho and Dembele...they are close.\n\n\"We hope they will be Barca players next season.\"\n\nBarca's season has been thrown into turmoil by Neymar's world record 222 million euro ($261 million) move to Paris Saint-Germain earlier this month.\n\nNew Barca coach Ernesto Valverde admitted Neymar's absence has affected the balance of the side.\n\nMeanwhile, the Catalans have struggled to close deals for Coutinho and Dembele with Liverpool and Dortmund holding out for fees in excess of 100 million euros in the knowledge of Barca's desperation to land a replacement before the transfer window shuts on August 31.\n\nBarca defender Gerard Pique denied reports there is a growing feud between club's players and under-pressure board.\n\nHowever, Pique admitted Barca have plenty of work to do if they are to close they gap on Madrid, who have added to their crowns as European and Spanish champions by winning both the UEFA and Spanish Super Cups in style over the past week.\n\n\"We are not in the best moment. Not as a team or as a club,\" said Pique.\n\n\"We have to stick together and move forward.\n\n\"The season is long and it has just begun. Madrid were superior so we have to live with defeat, congratulate them and improve.\"\n\nNO RONALDO, NO PROBLEM\n\nDespite missing the suspended Cristiano Ronaldo, whose five-game ban for pushing a referee after being sent off in the first leg was upheld on appeal before kick-off, Madrid were dominant in the first-half.\n\nMarco Asensio's brilliant strike after just four minutes built on Madrid's 3-1 first leg lead and Karim Benzema doubled the hosts' lead on the night just before half-time.\n\nVictory also sealed Madrid's seventh trophy of a spectacularly successful spell since Zinedine Zidane took charge just 20 months ago.\n\n\"We are delighted with how we played in both games, it is another trophy and you have to congratulate the players because they have been fantastic,\" said Zidane.\n\nOn top of the absent Ronaldo, the Frenchman also had the luxury of leaving Gareth Bale and Isco on the bench as the gulf between Madrid and Barca's strength in depth was for his Barcelona move, Liverpool understands the lasting consequences of letting their star man go this summer.\n\nThe Brazilian's transfer saga holds the potential to swing both his and the Merseyside club's fortunes for years to come.\n\nAnd while the club continues to hold out, at what point does their blind refusal become fiscally irresponsible?\n\nWith the deal edging closer to some semblance of a resolution, Liverpool fans are still trying to come to terms with the fact that their star man wants out.\n\nAn all too familiar feeling, Coutinho's situation revives unwanted memories for a fan base that still mourns the loss of Luis Suarez to Barcelona just three years ago.\n\nAfter securing Champions League football for the season ahead, and adding Mohamed Salah at the start of the transfer window, things were looking up for Reds fans.\n\nA couple months down the road and the enthusiasm surrounding their Premier League season has taken a hit.\n\nUnable to bring in their two main summer targets, Naby Keita and Virgil van Dijk, along with Adam Lallana's injury and Coutinho's expected departure, Liverpool's title challenge is seemingly unravelling just one game into the season.\n\nFor Liverpool fans, they're again at the mercy of Barcelona's universal pull and after stealing Suarez, the big, bad giants want another.\n\nStill reeling from Neymar's world record departure, Barca chiefs are desperate to save face with fans by re-investing that astronomical fee.\n\nAnd after their comical showing in the Spanish Super Cup, fans expect a statement of intent from a club teetering on the edge of (relative) disaster.\n\nSo, whether it's Coutinho or someone else, they will be spending that money.\n\nAnd Coutinho knows that.\n\nAt a club the size and stature of Barcelona, doors open and close quickly, and if you aren't ready when they come knocking, you can't expect them to wait around.\n\nAnd that's why Coutinho is pushing for the move but it's also why Liverpool are so intent on hanging on to him.\n\nBoth player and club know that timing is everything in world football and if it doesn't happen now, it might never happen.\n\nWould the Brazilian be agitating for a transfer so aggressively if Barca could guarantee they'll be back in - and can afford him still - next summer, or the one after that?\n\nAlmost certainly not.\n\nCome next summer, the Catalan giants may have moved on and his dream move would remain just that: a dream.\n\nCoutinho's rapid descent from being content with life at Liverpool, to the utter madness that has since transpired is a lesson in the cutthroat nature of football at the highest level.\n\nWhile the Reds of Merseyside rue the Brazilian's actions, criticising his handling of the whole situation, was there any other way to force this deal through?\n\nAfter Klopp and FSG insisted time and time again that Liverpool were not a selling club and that they wouldn't listen to any offers, Coutinho really only had one more trick up his sleeve, and he played it.\n\nAnd he's not the first, nor will he be the last player to do so.\n\nWhile no one forced Coutinho to sign his extension at the start of the year, contracts work as more of a price influencer nowadays than a full-proof obstacle to a transfer.\n\nBut, when clubs throw logic out the window and refuse to so much as discuss a transfer, desperate players are left with only one option.\n\nOne doesn't need to look further than the Liverpool fans encouraging and applauding Virgil van Dijk's fight for his Southampton exit.\n\nOr Barcelona's second summer target Ousmane Dembele's mysterious disappearing act.\n\nThere is a tangible frustration among Reds fans as they watch Coutinho succeed in forcing his way out, in a way that Keita and van Dijk were seemingly unable to.\n\nAnd while Coutinho's departure may sting, a proposed \u00a3120m deal - although the composition and timing of it is now being questioned - is a massively inflated fee for a player that has, some would argue, had one season of consistent, elite production.\n\nFor all of Liverpool's fighting talk, just how rational is it to turn down an offer that almost doubles the fee {"id": "9714512", "categories": [{"id": 32, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Football/American", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Football/American", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 51, "label": "dmoz/Games/Video Games/Recreation", "uri": "dmoz/Games/Video_Games/Recreation", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 134, "label": "dmoz/Games/Video Games/Downloads", "uri": "dmoz/Games/Video_Games/Downloads", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 220, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Baseball/Youth", "wgt": 100}, {"id": 383, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy", "wgt": 100}], "date": "2017-08-17", "uri": "710946257", "source": {"id": "305", "title": "Economic Times", "uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com"}, "url": "http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/sports/liverpools-coutinho-still-injured-no-attitude-problem-says-klopp/articleshow/60105669.cms", "body": "Coutinho, who submitted a transfer request last week according to British media reports, missed Liverpool's 3-3 draw at Watford last Saturday and the first leg of their Champions League playoff, a 2-1 win over Hoffenheim on Tuesday.\n\n\"Phil is not available. Not in training so far,\" Klopp told reporters on Thursday, adding that he had nothing negative to say about the player's attitude.\n\nBarcelona's sporting manager Pep Segura said on Wednesday that the Spanish club were \"close\" to signing Coutinho, despite Liverpool's manager and owners saying the 25-year-old is not for sale.\n\nKlopp said on Thursday that nothing had changed with their stance.\n\n\"I don't know why other people are saying what they're saying (about Coutinho moving to Barcelona). I don't even know him (Segura). I have never met him,\" Klopp said.\n\n\"We are not silly, we know it is a very difficult situation - but there's nothing new to say. It's not always easy for me to say the 100 percent truth... But this time this is the situation.\"\n\nFans have expressed frustration with Liverpool's failure to invest further in a squad that finished fourth in the Premier League last season, but Klopp said that he was happy with the players he has already.\n\n\"The whole market is difficult,\" Klopp said.\n\n\"If the transfer window had ended yesterday we already have a team I like. Site regular Case has requested another poll to gauge the prevailing view amongst Reds fans, so here it is:\n\nIn my view, Liverpool should just sell Coutinho ASAP for as much money as possible. He is no longer the future of LFC, so there's no point keeping him. Plus, for all ability, Coutinho's goals/assists record has never been that impressive:\n\n* Goals: Personal best = 14 in one season. Average: 9 per season (all competitions)\n\n* Assists: Personal best = 9 in one season. Average: 8 per season (all competitions)\n\nAre we seriously to believe that Liverpool is incapable of replacing an attacking player who contributes a meager 8 assists every season in ALL competitions? Coutinho's primary role is to create and score goals, but his goals/assist return is merely average. Plus, n terms of minutes-per-goal/assist, Coutinho is near the bottom of the pile in a 4-year comparative analysis of players who operate in similar positions (as I've illustrated with detailed stats in the past)\n\nCoutinho may well improve his output at Barcelona, but where Liverpool are concerned, Coutinho is replaceable. If the Reds can bring in a player who consistently contributes 20-25 goals/assists every season, then personally, I'll be happy with that, even if said player isn't as talented as Coutinho.\n\nThat said, scoring is not Liverpool's problem. Even without Coutinho this season, the club has players who can (and will) score the requisite number of goals. Salah, for example, will (in all probability) pick up the Coutinho slack, which means Liverpool will lose very little overall in the goals/assists department.\n\nWe're not talking about a player who consistently has a Luis Suarez-type impact on the team (!). Coutinho's end product is average, yet despite that, he is currently at the apex of his transfer value. {"id": "9967065", "categories": [], "date": "2017-08-18", "uri": "711632605", "source": {"id": "886", "title": "ProSoccerTalk", "uri": "soccer.nbcsports.com"}, "url": "http://soccer.nbcsports.com/2017/08/18/liverpool-holds-all-the-cards-in-coutinho-saga/", "body": "In a time of heightening player control in a rapidly expanding transfer market, one club sticks out as grasping a clear understanding of the shifting business landscape and how to retain its grip on its most valuable assets.\n\nFollowing the sudden departure of superstar playmaker Neymar, Barcelona is trying desperately to pry Philippe Coutinho from Liverpool. On Friday, numerous reports in England claimed that Barcelona had gone in with a third bid, one even more ridiculous than the previous two. But they're fighting a losing battle.\n\nFor a number of reasons, the Reds hold complete control over Philippe Coutinho's transfer saga, a saga that will likely end with no transfer having been completed.\n\nFirst and foremost, Coutinho just recently signed a contract extension in January that runs through 2022. As far as we know, there is no release clause in the deal, meaning at the most basic of levels, Liverpool maintains contractual control. However, as we've seen the past few years, that alone hasn't stopped a number of players forcing their way out.\n\nYet this time, Liverpool finds itself in an advantageous position outside of just the contract. With the 2018 World Cup right around the corner, the Reds know that should they force Coutinho to stay, he is obligated to play at his best, knowing that any less would see him miss out on a spot in the packed Brazil roster, or at the least a starting position. Thus, Liverpool can be sure that even if their denial of his departure renders him despondent, he will likely remain the quality player he has proven to be.\n\nThe money Barcelona is offering - a whopping $151 million according to the most recent reports - is indeed a ludicrous amount for a player who, while quality, does not have nearly the marketability of his countrymate now residing in Paris. On talent alone, Coutinho likely isn't worth that total, meaning Liverpool should sell. And yet, even with that cash in hand, in this hyper-inflated market where more is less, could it really do justice in replacing his impact in the club? This late in the transfer window, there's no chance they could replace the 25-year-old, meaning they'd likely be torpedoing their entire season - Champions League included - to feel the warmth of $151 million burning a hole in their pocket until January, or even next summer.\n\nLiverpool has built its entire roster around Coutinho. The arrival of Salah, the use of Firmino, the wide deployment of Mane, the makeup of the midfield. He's good enough and young enough to be considered a \"franchise player.\" In two games without Coutinho this season, they've scored five goals, but that is a poor metric to describe the 180 wild minutes. The money alone isn't worth the cost of his departure.\n\nIt's quite possible that Barcelona's stubbornness, brought on by the sudden loss of a beloved player and the meteoric rise of their rivals to all-time greatness, could see the Catalans come back with an even more preposterous bid. It's true every player has a value, and at some point, should Barcelona's blind rage see them flail wildly into the transfer window, the Reds should sell, and will. But with Fenway Sports Group not in dire need of cash and in an advantageous position, in all likelihood they won't. Barcelona can throw all the Neymar money at Liverpool their heart desires, but nothing will force the Reds to budge.", "dateTime": "2017-08-18T19:56:00Z", "extractedDates": null, "sim": "http://www.nation.co.ke/sports/football/Dortmund-deny-Dembeles-sale-to-Barca-is-close/1102-4061342-fbucb/index.html", "body": "Watzke's comments referred to Segura's claim on Wednesday that Barcelona are \"close\" to completing a deal for Dembele as well as Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho.\n\nBorussia Dortmund's CEO Hans-Joachim Watzke on Thursday rubbished claims by Barcelona's general manager Pep Segura that the Spanish giants were 'close' to signing the German club's want-away winger Ousmane Dembele.\n\n\"Barcelona have not managed to fulfil their wish to complete Dembele's transfer -- until now, they aren't one millimetre closer,\" Watzke told German magazine Kicker.\n\nWatzke's comments referred to Segura's claim on Wednesday that Barcelona are \"close\" to completing a deal for Dembele as well as Liverpool's Philippe Coutinho.\n\nDembele, 20, has a contract until 2021 and was suspended indefinitely by Dortmund last week for skipping training in a personal protest to pressure the German club to sell him to Barcelona.\n\nThe Frenchman is suspended for Dortmund's opening Bundesliga match against Wolfsburg on Saturday, which is an unwelcome distraction for new Borussia coach Peter Bosz.\n\n\"It is not possible to completely blend it out, but I try to focus on the players who are here, which he isn't,\" said Bosz when asked about Dembele.\n\n\"I don't know what will happen, we have to be patient for a few more days.\"\n\nSpanish giants Barcelona want to sign both Dembele and Coutinho as attacking reinforcements after losing Neymar to Paris Saint-Germain.\n\nAccording to Spanish media, Barcelona are offering 80 million euros ($93.5 million, \u00a372.7 million), plus a bonus of 40 million euros, but Dortmund want 150 million euros for Dembele -- 10 times what they paid Rennes in 2016.\n\nDembele's decision to strike has irked his team-mates.\n\nHe missed Saturday's 4-0 win at minnows Rielasingen-Arlen in the first round of the German Cup when Gabon hot-shot Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang scored a hat-trick.\n\nDortmund's tough-tackling defender Sokratis Papastathopoulos says Dembele should follow the example of Aubameyang, who has been linked to a big-money move to China but has been told that he is staying.\n\n\"Ousmane is a good lad, but he has to recognise that no player is bigger than the team,\" Sokratis told Thursday's edition of magazine Kicker.\n\n\"Everyone has to be clear that he must work for the team and fall in line. This also applies to Ousmane -- he can't just do whatever he wants.\"\n\n\"Ousmane has done no good by going on strike. Then we will see,\" said Sokratis.\n\n\"Ousmane has given a lot for us.
